title: Tomorrow’s Shore EP
label: Wichita
description: These leftovers from the UK band’s 2017 reunion album successfully position them in a contemporary context alongside peers like Tame Impala and Caribou.

title: In a Poem Unlimited
label: 4AD
description: Meg Remy is a narrative savant and her glorious, danceable new album is a righteous collection of razor-sharp songs, full of spit and fury, a high-water mark for political pop music.

title: Dear Annie
label: 300 Entertainment
description: This Irish rapper's debut suggests great potential, even if he's limited for now by the obvious influence of N.E.R.D and Tyler, the Creator.

title: Room Inside the World
label: Merge
description: Ought’s third album straightens out their sound, offering a more refined new wave palette underneath their singular and compelling lyrical style.

title: A Whole Fucking Lifetime of This
label: Run for Cover
description: The band formerly known as Teen Suicide has a fresh outlook on life. Their new album might be the best thing frontman Sam Ray has made so far.

title: The Boy With the Arab Strap
label: Jeepster
description: The Scottish band’s excellent third album features some of their darkest and most detailed songs. Wholly beautiful and delicate, it was Stuart Murdoch’s first reluctant step into the spotlight.

title: By the Way, I Forgive You
label: Elektra
description: Carlile’s sixth LP is a move toward her prestige era, a moment when she’s expected to reconcile the warring parts of herself for a growing audience.

title: Sir
label: Ultra
description: The electroclash duo returns from a nine-year hiatus with a new creative brain trust in tow, but a few standout singles aren’t enough to redeem a plodding, repetitive album.

title: Few Traces
label: Rvng Intl.
description: A new reissue resurfaces the music of a cult-favorite songwriter from 1980s Baltimore who drew on ambient and British pop influences.

title: Way Out West
label: Craft
description: Recorded in Los Angeles in 1957, the jazz legend’s classic album—the first to use the now-standard saxophone-bass-drums trio—looks like a novelty and sounds like transcendence.

title: Glass
label: NOTON
description: In a live recording from a site-specific 2016 performance at Philip Johnson’s iconic Glass House, the Japanese polymath and the German minimalist balance piercing tones with emotional warmth.

title: Twin Fantasy
label: Matador
description: Will Toledo’s re-recorded version of an album originally released in 2011 speaks to his greatest gifts as a songwriter: wit, cynicism, and an eye for detail that captures young desire and heartache.

title: Brighter Wounds
label: City Slang
description: On the synth-rock project’s fifth album, the stakes feel higher, with new fatherhood and the perilous state of the world inspiring searching introspection and dramatic gestures.

title: Wait for Love
label: Epitaph
description: The intensely serious post-hardcore band marks the turn from death and loss to life and love with nimble musicianship, inventive rhythms, and Kyle Durfey’s most accomplished singing yet.

title: Travels in Constants EP
label: Temporary Residence
description: Recorded in 2000 and newly reissued, the sprawling title track and its B-side are a defining precursor to the contemplative works Jason Molina would soon create and release under his own name.

title: The Secret Life of Planets
label: self-released
description: Zaki Ibrahim’s second album is a future-soul marvel that connects sounds across time and oceans, creating thrilling moments of pop music synthesized through her wise and worldly vision.

title: Unsolved Mysteries
label: Ultramajic
description: Discovered gathering dust in an old storage unit, the Detroit artist’s lost album from the ’90s is an interesting curio that slots nicely alongside techno’s current renaissance.

title: Effected
label: Dreamville
description: For his second album on J. Cole’s imprint, Cozz is beginning to build his own style while finding how to maneuver between the boisterous and introspective.

title: Music for the Long Emergency
label: Totally Gross National Product
description: The Minneapolis synth-pop band teams up with a Berlin-based orchestra in an attempt to reckon with the trials of our time.

title: Cranberry
label: Double Double Whammy
description: The Austin indie-pop duo’s music conjures a steady, gentle longing. Foggy, warm, and wistful, it sounds like faded time.

title: Slow Sundown
label: Wharf Cat
description: This Estonian band’s debut album sounds like a long, lonely drive on a moonlit night, with plenty of guitar reverb.

title: The Play Don’t Care Who Makes It EP
label: Def Jam
description: On his reflective four-song EP, the Atlanta rapper’s hallmark frivolity and infinite swag keep it short and sweet.

title: Order of Torment
label: Relapse
description: The D.C. death metal band attacks with pummeling force and socially pointed lyrics, in the tradition of Bolt Thrower and Incantation.

title: Tongue
label: Friends of Friends
description: The Los Angeles-based producer retreats to the hills of Tuscany to further the vision of eclectic mix of woodwinds, synthesizers, and field recordings.

title: Crush EP
label: Atlantic
description: The Chicago R&B upstart pairs with producer Steve Lacy for five tracks of inventive modernist soul.

title: High Rise II
label: Black Editions
description: Originally released in 1986, the reissue of High Rise II shines a light on an important and fiery document of Japanese psych rock.

title: Black Panther The Album
label: Top Dawg
description: Curated by and largely featuring Kendrick Lamar, the soundtrack is a diverse, daring, and holistic pairing with the blackest movie in the Marvel Comic Universe.

title: Cloud 909
label: Good Vibe Tribe
description: The duo’s grab-bag approach continues on their third studio album, an 18-track marathon with more good than bad but little of substance.

title: Dead Start Program
label: Kompakt
description: The Los Angeles producer’s house and techno is hyper-attuned to the nuances of timbre, giving his music a captivating textural focus even when emotion is in scant supply.

title: Pure Beauty
label: Third Man
description: The first rapper on Jack White’s label, known mostly for the publicity stunts in his past, loves conceptual art, ’90s hip-hop, and grand statements

title: Transangelic Exodus
label: Bella Union
description: The singer-songwriter’s latest album features a sweeping backstory about supernatural queer lovers on the run and a lurid, cinematic new sound.

title: Stankonia
label: La Face
description: What could’ve been a victory lap for two Southern rappers on top of the game was instead a transcendental funk fantasia, an unequivocal commercial and artistic triumph.

title: Posthuman
label: Metal Blade
description: The swole Chicago hardcore band’s latest album shows their raw strength while adding shades of industrial and groove metal for character.

title: Crooked Shadows
label: Fueled by Ramen
description: The emo lifer’s seventh album tries to balance intimacy and accessibility, but he only ends up with the latter.

title: Go Dig My Grave
label: SusannaSonata
description: The Norwegian vocalist offers spare, chilly covers of songs from post-punk Manchester, 1970s New York, and Elizabethan England.

title: How to Measure the Distance Between Lovers EP
label: never_b_alone.mp3
description: The rising EDM star swerves left on an insular, personal record that's more suited for winding down than turning up.

title: Rock Island
label: Carpark
description: On their second album, the wildly inventive art-rock band works harder than ever to unburden itself of the influences heard in its earlier work.

title: The Two Worlds
label: Tompkins Square
description: The second album from the singer-songwriter is a dizzyingly isolated record, spare and serene music that gains momentum as it burrows deeper.

title: Little Dark Age
label: Columbia
description: MGMT’s fourth album marks a shift in tactics. Abandoning the belabored excess of their last two albums, they opt for streamlined synth-pop.

title: Drip Season 3
label: YSL
description: This Young Thug protégé’s latest mixtape locks in on a vibe and rolls wherever it goes. Usually it doesn’t go too far.

title: Dream Wife
label: Lucky Number
description: The UK rock band’s debut is a prime example of what happens when you grow up on Bikini Kill and the Slits.

title: Always Ascending
label: Domino
description: At its best, the fifth album from the UK indie-rock stalwarts is sleek, catchy, and enjoyably overwrought, the sound of a snappy hype band no longer burdened by relevance.

title: Metal Aether
label: NNA Tapes
description: The New York composer is an electro-acoustic minimalist who pays special attention to the spaces around her. Her latest album, by turns grounded and disquieting, feels untethered and limitless.

title: Pissing Stars
label: Constellation
description: The Godspeed You! Black Emperor co-founder’s second album searches for love in the middle of a hellscape, with surprising shades of Springsteen.

title: Criminal
label: Sacred Bones
description: On his fourth album as the Soft Moon, post-punk auteur Luis Vasquez finally breaks from a whisper into a scream.

title: If You’re Into It, I’m Out of It
label: Cross Fade Entertainment
description: Originally released in 1997, the German producer’s world of mythic drones and breakbeats is newly remastered and remains a blistering and confrontational touchstone of electronic music.

title: There Will Be Rain
label: Grand Closing
description: The Bronx rapper’s second solo album grapples with questions of faith over jazz and gospel production.

title: Early Tape Works (1986-1993) Vol.1
label: Music From Memory
description: Produced using analog synths, drum machines, and four-track tape, these ambient sketches and beat experiments reveal the foundations of the Japanese producer’s later, more elaborate work.

title: Amen
label: EMPIRE
description: The debut from Rich Brian has the fun, wit, and snark of a choice tweet but lacks the essential qualities of a solid well-made rap album.

title: The Book Room
label: Marionette
description: Drawing principally from minimalism, ambient, and krautrock, Swiss producer Benjamin Kilchhofer’s latest is a deeply immersive timbral and tactile experience.

title: ION
label: Profound Lore
description: The Australian band delivers a jarring, dissonant record of non-linear death metal filtered through a necro black-metal screen, with a crisp high end that brings out every jagged turn.

title: Mitteltöner
label: Origin Peoples
description: For his first vinyl release of new music in 25 years, Kerry Leimer makes explicit his debt to kosmische music while recasting these sounds into his own mold.

title: Full Circle Nightmare
label: Sub Pop
description: This Portland songwriter’s second album is full of femme fatales and other clichés dredged from a half-century of classic rock.

title: Microshift
label: Domino
description: The English psych-punks turn down the distortion and face their demons with a new, synth-y sound on their third album.

title: Island Universe Story Four
label: Rvng Intl.
description: Roberto Lange’s fourth installment in his Island Universe series contains subconscious whisperings that provide a map for the music he’s been making as Helado Negro for the last eight years.

title: Blood
label: Loma Vista
description: The second album from Michael Milosh and his soft-rock musicians deftly creates an atmosphere that builds out their sound without adding much underneath.

title: The Well-Tuned Piano 81 X 25 6:17:50 - 11:18:59 PM NYC
label: Gramavision
description: The masterpiece from the preeminent minimalist composer is an as-yet-unfinished piano solo played on a piano tuned specifically to elicit unfamiliar emotions from unfamiliar harmonies.

title: Quit the Curse
label: Polyvinyl
description: On her solo debut, the Detroit singer-songwriter cuts with her folk-rock past and turns to 1960s-indebted indie pop and 1990s-schooled alt-rock hooks.

title: Cosmic Crypt
label: Relapse
description: Austin musician Chris Ulsh’s longest-running band returns with a revitalized lineup and a new commitment to death metal intensity.

title: 起き上がり
label: Doom Trip
description: Recorded live with no overdubs, Maxwell Allison’s latest electronic album is more groove-oriented than his previous work, his hardware noise sounding both vintage and pristine.

title: Pulse/Quartet
label: Nonesuch
description: Though detailed and accomplished, Steve Reich’s latest work dully reaffirms his place as a centrist in a field of extremists.

title: Outside
label: Atlantic
description: Following an all-too-brief turn on Drake’s More Life, one of Nigeria’s preeminent musical ambassadors shares his own hybrid vision, drawing on Afrobeats, dancehall, and road rap.

title: Man of the Woods
label: RCA
description: Justin Timberlake’s fifth album is a huge misstep for the pop star. It is warm, indulgent, inert, and vacuous.

title: Lionheart
label: Merge
description: Released on Merge Records, the singer-songwriter’s debut is a gorgeous devotional to the South that reshapes the traditions of country music into a powerfully queer and consequential set of songs.

title: Open Here
label: Memphis Industries
description: The UK art-rock duo’s new album has the earnest directness of artists whose sense of the world has been nudged into focus.

title: Follow Them True
label: From Here
description: Respecting folk music’s past while uprooting it from the pastoral, the UK group’s politically minded album mixes acoustic and electronic instruments across original songs and traditionals.

title: Con Todo El Mundo
label: Night Time Stories Ltd.
description: On their second album, the Houston-based instrumental trio crafts a unique, psychedelic vibe that hangs between continents and eras.

title: D’Agala
label: Intakt
description: The Swiss-born jazz pianist’s second album with this group is animated by a spirit of playful experimentation.

title: Slow Fade EP
label: Phantasy
description: The UK producer expands into ambient territory, finding drama in negative spaces and downtempo explorations.

title: Impossible Star
label: self-released
description: Influential sample maestro Jack Dangers’ first album since 2010 is a moody, playful exhibition of his strengths.

title: Veteran
label: Deathbomb Arc
description: The 28-year-old rapper’s latest album is a glitchy, frantic, confrontational album on both a musical and political level. It feels born of an internet wasteland.

title: Aren’t U Glad You’re U?
label: Odd Future
description: The sleepiest rapper in Odd Future teams up with an old-school mentor for a short, low-stakes mixtape.

title: Young & Reckless
label: 300 Entertainment
description: On an unexpected collaborative mixtape, the two previously unconnected rappers hone their complementary styles in gloomy songs shot through with paranoia.

title: Oh My
label: Father/Daughter
description: On their debut as a trio, Phantom Posse singer-songwriter Nadia Hulett and members of Ava Luna play with open-ended questions and experimental pop zest.

title: Culture II
label: Quality Control
description: Where Culture was an event, its follow-up feels more like an occurrence, the quality of its songs handicapped by an album that plays like a long and formless grab bag.

title: Love Jail
label: Thrill Jockey
description: The trio’s second album buffs away some of its debut’s grime and distortion for a set of knotty, pummeling rock that sounds vintage but feels current.

title: Big Bossin Vol. 2
label: Def Jam
description: The Detroit rapper and the Dallas producer team up for another satin-smooth album of street hustler stories.

title: Make Me Know You Sweet
label: West Mineral Ltd.
description: The Kansas City artist better known as Huerco S. continues a recent string of ambient investigations with foggy, ambivalent tracks shot through with a sense of anxiety.

title: Pèze-Piton
label: 12th Isle
description: Mixing up elements of kuduro, dancehall, baile funk, and other global sounds, the Berlin-based producer channels the sound of traveling with no fixed destination in mind.

title: Could It Be Different?
label: Slumberland
description: The idealistic, politically-minded Scottish indie-pop band gloss up their sound on album three.

title: The Brown Tape
label: Mello Music Group
description: An alternate version of Ghostface’s 2013 album 12 Reasons to Die, produced by Detroit’s Apollo Brown, features beats that suit the rapper’s strengths more closely.

title: Snares Like a Haircut
label: Drag City
description: The noise-rock duo’s fifth album is a fresh and clear-eyed statement, drawing most from punk’s impulse towards attentiveness and honesty.

title: All Eyez on Me
label: Death Row
description: Tupac’s 1996 double album was made in a frenzy. It is paranoid and brazen, fun and fearless, but it is Pac’s singular style that keeps one of his greatest records from coming undone at the seams.

title: Vessel of Love
label: Merge
description: On her pristine third album, Hollie Cook, a UK singer and one-time Slits member, draws upon 1970s reggae in songs about love and resilience.

title: Fleetwood Mac
label: Warner Bros.
description: Though far from their debut, the band’s 1975 self-titled album felt like a debut: a pop-rock statement and the unexpected intersection of two parallel spheres that offered something genuinely new.

title: More Disco Songs About Love
label: Innovative Leisure
description: The sort-of disco duo has got the hooks and the groove but on their third album, they struggle to find their footing.

title: Weather or Not
label: Rhymesayers
description: The Dilated Peoples MC’s third solo album shows his continued faith in the eternal truths of boom-bap rap music.

title: Beautiful Despair
label: Fire
description: A lost album from the UK post-punk greats, recorded circa 1989, sheds light on the creative process of brilliant, troubled frontman Dan Treacy.

title: Fabriclive 96
label: Fabric
description: On his Fabriclive mix, UK producer Skream struggles to settle on a vibe.

title: Freedom’s Goblin
label: Drag City
description: On his excellent and ambitious double album, the tuneful sensibility that Segall has been nurturing for years has fully blossomed, all while keeping his primordial spirit intact.

title: The Thread That Keeps Us
label: Anti-
description: The reliable Southwestern indie-rockers’ ninth album is full of impassioned stories about border politics and environmental disasters.

title: The Time Is Now
label: Insanity
description: A veteran of UK garage and R&B, Craig David follows up his 2016 comeback by fishing for current trends to keep him relevant.

title: Down Below
label: Century Media
description: Traditionalists no more, the Swedish band spend their fourth album exploring the divide between metal’s underground and mainstream.

title: Digital Rain
label: ITALIANS DO IT BETTER
description: The latest solo album from the leader of Chromatics is a full-scale concept album about inclement weather.

title: Marble Skies
label: Ribbon Music
description: The mad scientists of UK psych-rock take an unexpected turn toward pop on their third album.

title: Highly Caffeinated
label: self-released
description: Paying tribute to an idealized era of hip-hop that predated his birth, the 18-year-old Detroit musician proves himself a gifted rapper who’s overinvested in ideas past their sell-by date.

title: Un Peu De L’Âme Des Bandits
label: Crammed Discs
description: Originally released in 1980, the newly reissued second album from the Belgian art-rockers is a knotty experiment that freely slams together the sounds of contemporary classical music and free jazz.

title: All Melody
label: Erased Tapes
description: Recorded in the storied Funkhaus studio in Germany, All Melody is pianist Nils Frahm’s grandest statement yet, yet it maintains the inquisitive, exploratory spirit of his most playful recordings.

title: what people call low self​-​esteem is really just seeing yourself the way that other people see you
label: self-released
description: The San Jose emo band’s debut sounds like various states of alarm, a big statement that leans on the raw impulses of singer and songwriter Shannon Taylor.

title: I Can Feel You Creep Into My Private Life
label: 4AD
description: On her confrontational fourth album, Merrill Garbus wades into the politics of being white in America. It is musically and lyrically ambitious, but its grander themes land with an uncomfortable thud.

title: The Worm’s Heart
label: Columbia
description: James Mercer takes his most recent album through the looking glass, flipping songs’ tempos and production styles on an eccentric mission of discovery.

title: LiE
label: Sub Pop
description: The grunge survivors leap back into the moshpit of time on a live album culled from their 2016 tour of Europe.

title: Chris Dave and the Drumhedz
label: Blue Note
description: Though its many guest vocalists can be distracting, the Houston-born musician’s debut album presents a strong argument for the drummer as a modern bandleader.

title: The House
label: Domino
description: The New York-based songwriter Aaron Maine stays in the lane of writing delicate, evocative songs with homespun beats, but he never quite locks into the kind of groove that made his last record Pool so satisfying.

title: Paranoia 2
label: Def Jam
description: On his third release in less than six months, the New York rapper is at his sharpest, offering a nostalgic but refreshed taste of the city’s so-called Rotten Apple rap era.

title: Cadence Weapon
label: eOne
description: The rapper and former Edmonton poet laureate’s first album in six years unpacks his history as a hip-hop advocate and explores the inner workings of Canadian beat communities.

title: Blue Madonna
label: Interscope
description: The second album from the rapidly ascending synth-pop artist Garrett Borns offers more of the same: great ideas constrained in songs that rarely allow them to come to fruition.

title: Love/Hate
label: Island Def Jam
description: The-Dream crafted an absolutely exquisite album for his 2007 solo debut. It is a defining moment for the collision of rap and R&B and a pillar of technical songwriting and soulful expression.

title: Between Two Shores
label: Anti-
description: On his latest solo album, the Irish folk singer sets sail on a journey of the heart, full of sad break-up songs and meandering musings.

title: Time Flying Beats
label: Leaving
description: On his latest album, a luminary of the Los Angeles beat scene remembers how to come back down from the astral plane and hits the dance floor running.

title: Rich Hood
label: EMPIRE
description: Gucci Mane’s latest protégé, a smooth-talking rapper with a nonchalant charm, steps into the spotlight after a streak of well-liked mixtapes.

title: Something/Anything? / A Wizard, a True Star
label: Analog Spark
description: The wildly ambitious albums that cemented Rundgren’s legend as a studio genius in the early 1970s return in illuminating new editions.

title: The Official Body
label: Fat Cat
description: The third record from the UK trio wrangles their elastic, post-punk spirit into an urgency that feels bonded to the present. It makes for songs that are as mesmerizing as they are exhilarating.

title: Voice Hardcore
label: Mesh-Key
description: Using mainly her resilient voice and some electronic effects, the latest record from the Japanese underground legend draws parallels to the punk impulse with her extended, avant-garde vocal excursions.

title: Semicircle
label: Memphis Industries
description: On their fifth album, the Go! Team look to the Motor City for their 1960s fix; they’re as boisterous as ever, but their nostalgia doesn’t dip far beneath the surface of their inspirations.

title: Ruins
label: Columbia
description: The Swedish folk duo’s fourth album is a showcase for their sweet harmonies, with some bold stylistic departures.

title: Somewhere Else
label: Wharf Cat
description: On their quietly commanding darkwave record, songwriter Noah Anthony and poet Elaine Kahn use harsh noise and power electronics to show it’s possible to care for chaos.

title: Into One Name
label: Genome 6.66 Mbp
description: On his new album for Shanghai’s Genome Tapes, London’s Tim Zha applies Auto-Tuned vocals to hybrid pop informed by dancehall and Afrobeats, where bright details dance against a blurry backdrop.

title: How to Solve Our Human Problems, Pt. 2
label: Matador
description: Having grown from wise-beyond-their-years aesthetes into middle-aged adults, Belle and Sebastian balance parental sentimentalism with a youthful abandon rarely entertained on their early recordings.

title: November
label: Top Dawg
description: The Inglewood artist’s first album as Kendrick and SZA’s labelmate is a neo-soul-tinged space odyssey about love.

title: Songs of Praise
label: Dead Oceans
description: On their debut album, the UK rock group separates themselves from their peers, imbuing their post-adolescent rage with wit and, crucially, a self-effacing awareness that they may never succeed.

title: Camila
label: Epic
description: The former Fifth Harmony member’s debut solo album is largely successful at capturing her charismatic flair. Anchored by the wonderful “Havana,” it shines especially when it's light and breezy.

title: The Dude
label: Super Audio CD
description: Jones’ all-star pop-soul adventure prefigured Thriller and highlighted his ear for new grooves.

title: Sekundenschlaf
label: Blackest Ever Black
description: A mysterious project from an unknown source sends listeners on an exhilarating goose chase through ambient techno and ethereal jungle.

title: Sun Ra Plays Gershwin
label: Enterplanetary Koncepts
description: A collection of George Gershwin interpretations by the avant-jazz legend traces his roots in the swing era, fleshing out a seldom-heard side of the astral voyager.

title: Vision Songs, Vol. 1
label: Numero Group
description: Numero Group turns up an outlier in the new-age icon’s catalog: an album of vocal music that, while a lesser work, offers a glimpse of a seldom-seen side of Laraaji.

title: Punken
label: TSO
description: The Houston rapper’s first mixtape since 2016 is full of unsparing storytelling, pusher anthems, and a dynamic array of trap production over which Maxo delivers some of his most effective writing.

title: Phantom Thread Original Motion Picture Soundtrack
label: Nonesuch
description: Recorded with a 60-piece orchestra, the Radiohead member’s score for Paul Thomas Anderson’s latest film is as lavish as its high-fashion, old-money backdrop.

title: Gumboot Soup
label: Flightless
description: The Aussie psych-rock group’s fifth album of 2017 is anything but a tossed-off afterthought, showing a new dedication to pop craftsmanship.

title: Life of a Dark Rose
label: self-released
description: The buzzing rapper’s debut mixtape is an easygoing 40 minutes of sugary trap and mellow, blissfully hazy vibe-music that runs with the sounds of the moment without advancing them much.

title: Winter in America
label: Strata-East
description: The 1974 album from the revolutionary singer and poet braided together his passion for music and literature. Its emotional pitch and fervent political tenor still resonates loudly in America today.

title: Weekend Rocker
label: Drunken Sailor
description: Halifax punks kick out the jams with plenty of distortion on their exhilaratingly rowdy second full-length.

title: Wrong Creatures
label: Vagrant
description: BRMC’s eighth album continues to prop up the rock-historical establishment. It offers more of the same, but at least it’s more of the same in a fairly compelling way.

title: Song of Silver Geese
label: Pi
description: The experimental jazz and classical composer’s newest work uses wildly divergent sounds to conjure a subtle, mournful mood.

title: G.O.A.T.
label: Griselda Records
description: Tough-talking Buffalo rapper, signed to Eminem’s Shady Records, offers ruthless rhymes and a stubbornly old-school sound on his latest album, featuring Raekwon, Prodigy, and more.

title: A Day With the Homies
label: Domino
description: Noah Lennox’s vinyl-only EP is a curious world apart, smeared with color and couched in his characteristic wordplay and deadpan humor.

title: Mr. Wollogallu
label: Urpa i musell
description: A cult-favorite Portuguese electronic album from the early ’90s with a pleasantly disorienting blend of instruments and textures.

title: El Gato: The Human Glacier
label: Atlantic
description: On his sixth album since re-starting his career post-jail, Gucci remains focused, funny, and at the top of his game.

title: No Dogs Allowed
label: self-released
description: This Boston singer-songwriter’s second proper album is a treasure trove of self-deprecating wit, melodic complexity, and endearingly anxious energy.

title: Just for Us
label: KTTF
description: On Francis Starlite’s third album, his music turns spare and stark as he comes closer to his finding his essence as a songwriter.

title: The Wasted Years
label: Fire
description: A new box set, collecting four albums released between 1983 and 1986, is a fascinating look at the early stages of an underrated UK post-punk act.

title: Nasty Gal
label: Light in the Attic
description: 1975’s Nasty Gal is another classic from one of the founders of funk. Davis and her band are a little sleazy, a little sultry, and show some surprising range on an album newly reissued on vinyl.

title: The Ghetto
label: 400 Summers
description: The South Central rapper RJMrLA follows up his official debut album with a full-length ride-along with DJ Mustard; the fruitful collaboration features some of the producer’s best work in years.

title: To Infinity
label: Topshelf
description: The Seattle indie rockers’ debut album places them in the lineage of bands like Modest Mouse and Built to Spill, wrapping majestically dejected songwriting in ambitiously atmospheric production.

title: sovereign nose of (y)​our arrogant face
label: Ruby Yacht
description: The witty, word-drunk Maine rapper (a.k.a. milo) follows up his 2017 breakthrough with a middle finger flipped in the direction of any remaining doubters.

title: Ephorize
label: self-released
description: The fearless Chicago rapper offers her best album yet, with terrific production and a barrage of raps that reveal Elizabeth Harris to be far more than her hilarious and absurdly raunchy one-liners.

title: Shells 2
label: Gingko
description: The latest solo project from Michigan guitarist Shelley Salant feels like a travelogue that uses simple lines of electric guitar to craft engaging tunes that say a lot without needing any words.

title: DH00278 (Live From The O2, London, 12/16/2016)
label: A Dirty Hit
description: The live album from one of the UK’s largest rock bands serves as a broad, if flawed, introduction to the still-growing band, their enormous potential, and the swaggeringly neurotic frontman Matt Healy.

title: Good Job No Conversation
label: Ultra
description: Channeling Sade, covering James Blake, and indulging in some silk-sheets saxophone, the Danish pop producer William Asingh makes a plush, playful, and quietly audacious debut.

title: Hats
label: Linn
description: The Scottish group’s 1989 cult classic is an album of euphoric love and loss that unfolds slowly and with starry eyes. Its noir mood and icy melodrama are still felt all over modern pop.

title: Urge to Merge
label: NNA Tapes
description: The Boston band’s second and final album is a bright explosion in every atonal direction from math-rock breakdowns to sludgy noise, like virtuosos pushing the self-destruct button.

title: Exposure
label: Concord
description: Written and recorded in just 77 hours, the bassist and singer’s limited-release album is a heady, jazzy range of intricacy and improvisation, a monument to her skills as a composer and performer.

title: Water Memory
label: self-released
description: Across its 40 minutes, the Los Angeles artist builds a modular synth album that is enveloping and cohesive. What initially sounds static may, upon closer examination, reveal a wealth of movement.

title: POST-
label: Quote Unquote
description: The magnetic Jeff Rosenstock stays fully armed with his power-pop anthems, as full of indomitable hooks as they are of paralyzing doubt and cynicism.

title: Cold Devil
label: Stinc Team
description: Cold Devil is the most compelling album of the Los Angeles emcee’s career. His avant deadpan and impressionistic relationship to the beat is hard to classify, but it’s icy and unforgettable.

title: Bright: The Album
label: Atlantic
description: None of the wild imagination fueling David Ayers’ bloated orc cop epic carries over to its soundtrack, which feels test-marketed to a fault.

title: Dedication 6
label: Young Money Entertainment
description: On the first Dedication mixtape installment in four years, Lil Wayne and DJ Drama show some of their former spark, but the tape does little to course-correct Wayne’s spiraling career trajectory.

title: Lady Bird (Original Motion Picture Soundtrack)
label: Lakeshore
description: Using piano, strings, a wind ensemble, and light percussion, Brion’s score subtly and deftly mirrors the existential ambling of Greta Gerwig’s outstanding coming-of-age film.

title: Trans-Millenia Music
label: Rvng Intl.
description: This anthology of self-released new age music from the 1980s captures a moment of spiritual questing, and it rightly rescues its creator from historical obscurity.

title: Virtual Self EP
label: self-released
description: Adopting a new alias, the EDM producer Porter Robinson sets aside Worlds’ electro-pop crossover and embraces early-2000s trance and video-game music.

title: Huncho Jack, Jack Huncho
label: Quality Control
description: The big personalities of both Quavo and Travis Scott are muted on their collaboration, one that feels lethargic even for a victory lap.

title: Ghosts
label: Lewis Hollow
description: The Sunny Day Real Estate singer returns from a long hiatus with a crowd-funded solo album that reconciles his singer/songwriter instincts with his lavish orchestral ambitions.

title: Lower East Suite Part One/Lower East Suite Part Two
label: Big Dada
description: Having collaborated with the likes of Dev Hynes and Princess Nokia—and teaming with streetwear brand Supreme—the New York jazz ensemble Onyx Collective honor their city on these latest releases.

title: Drum Dance to the Motherland
artist: The Khan Jamal Creative Arts Ensemble
label: Eremite
description: A long-forgotten gem of experimental jazz gets a welcome reissue 45 years after it was recorded in a Philadelphia basement; deep, adventurous, and soulful, it is a joy to discover.

title: Mercury’s Rainbow
label: Modern Love
description: Both naggingly familiar and singularly odd, Zomby’s previously unreleased 2008 album finds him putting his own quixotic stamp on grime’s classic eskibeat sound.

title: Merry Christmas Lil’ Mama: Re-Wrapped
label: self-released
description: Like the best holiday-themed art, Chance and Jeremih’s expanded reissue of their 2016 Christmas mixtape is part timeless, part time capsule.

title: Pressure
label: Def Jam
description: Jeezy is less effective these days, as his new album attests. But he covers gaps in his writing with a few tricks and guest appearances from Kendrick, Rick Ross, YG, 2 Chainz, and others.

title: Quiet Storm
label: 300 Entertainment
description: Capping off his breakout year, the D.C. rapper offers a deft album of soft synths and languid trap that further carves out his identity.

title: The Beautiful & Damned
label: RCA
description: The new album from Oakland rapper G-Eazy is a boozy, minor-key, 74-minute slog, where he wonders if it’s possible to survive the corrupting influence of celebrity.

title: A Home on Earth EP
label: self-released
description: The new EP from Portland duo the Body captures a rawer, more immediate side of the band. It documents their increasingly blurred boundaries between electronic noise and metal.

title: Pop 2
label: Asylum
description: Charli XCX’s latest mixtape is a vision of what pop music could be, the sound of an eclectic, hyperreal future where romantic love is fun but fucked and partying is an emotional refuge.

title: The Golden Ravedays
label: Hippie Dance
description: German producer Aksel Schaufler, aka Superpitcher, has long been a leading light of Cologne’s Kompakt label. His eclectic new solo album renews his commitment to duration—it’s nearly six hours long.

title: Revival
label: Aftermath
description: On his overtly political ninth studio LP, Eminem is fueled by self-doubt. But with many bland hooks and cringe-worthy punchlines, Revival is another late-career album that does little for his legacy.

title: No_One Ever Really Dies
label: N.E.R.D. Music
description: The new N.E.R.D. album is full of guests: Rihanna, Kendrick, Gucci, 3000, M.I.A., Wale, Ed Sheeran. They all help elevate an album that is occasionally ineffectual in its attempts at protest music.

title: Finding Shore
label: Dead Oceans
description: A collaboration between an improvising pianist and the ambient icon yields an unusual fusion of acoustic and electronic ideas—a meeting of minds that is full of rewarding surprises.

title: Rage Against the Machine
label: Epic
description: Rage Against the Machine’s debut is a radical fistful of funk, rap, and rock. Through its power, it remains an essential call to activism and a necessary lesson on how to withstand the opposition.

title: Wyclef Jean Inspired By...
label: self-released
description: A new mixtape from Wyclef Jean finds him reinterpreting the sound of 2017, track by track. There are endearing bits of serendipity here, but the project’s purpose is unclear.

title: Diggin’ in the Carts: A Collection of Pioneering Japanese Video Game Music
label: Hyperdub
description: Assembled by Hyperdub’s Steve Goodman and filmmaker Nick Dwyer, this 34-track compilation offers a retro-futurist deep dive into a lost world of incidental music of surprising power and poignancy.

title: Fela Kuti Box Set #4
label: Knitting Factory
description: Erykah Badu’s curated tour of the Afrobeat giant’s sprawling discography showcases the headier aspects of the legendary bandleader’s work, even as it grapples head-on with his life’s contradictions.

title: Bloodas
label: 300 Entertainment
description: Detroit rapper Tee Grizzley and Chicago drill alum Lil Durk team up for a promising mixtape that showcases their considerable chemistry.

title: Special Forces
label: NNA Tapes
description: The producer known as Ahnnu is affiliated with L.A.’s beat-music scene, but his sounds are swirling and gelatinous. Rhythms never unfold quite the way you might expect them to on his hypnotic new LP.

title: Saturation III
label: EMPIRE
description: It's on their third album this year that rap crew BROCKHAMPTON’s whole gestalt comes into focus. There are more memorable performances, and more fascinatingly unorthodox compositions servicing them.

title: Say Less
label: OVO Sound
description: OVO Sound signee Roy Wood$ offers a chilled-out version of trappy R&B on his debut studio album. But he’s yet to find a sound that is distinctly his own.

title: Laughing at the System EP
label: Alter
description: Absurdity is the guiding principle of the new EP from the Australian post-punk band. This delightfully bizarre release distills Total Control’s gnashing, dazzling appeal.

title: My House From All Angles
label: MoreAboutMusic
description: On his first solo LP in 27 years, house producer Mike Dunn celebrates the old school: Acid lines squirm, vintage drum machines knock and thrash, and Dunn holds court with his commanding baritone.

title: Tribute To 2
label: ATO
description: On a sequel to 2009’s covers collection Tribute To, the My Morning Jacket singer imbues a set of classics and standards with a distinctly contemporary melancholy.

label: Showoff
description: Statik Selektah, a hip-hop mainstay, brings Action Bronson, Joey Bada$$, Raekwon, Prodigy and more for a boppy, East Coast delight that doesn't make the best use of the producer’s intuition.

title: Double or Nothing
label: G.O.O.D. Music
description: Though fun and at times politically salient, even Metro Boomin cannot rescue Big Sean from his habit of writing the absolute corniest lyrics imaginable.

title: 2 Tha Left
label: So Way Out
description: West Coast rap nostalgist G Perico has spent 2017 on a forward-looking tear. His third full-length release of the year contains his immediate charm.

title: Highly Rare
label: International Anthem
description: Recorded live in Chicago and then rearranged in the drummer/producer’s studio, Highly Rare channels an electric night of raw improv into a shapeshifting form halfway between hip-hop and free jazz.

title: Universel
label: Melody As Truth
description: The latest from prolific Danish producer Natal Zaks is a short album of blissed-out, ambient textures, but is no less immersive thanks to his deft sense of world-building.

title: Quality Control: Control the Streets, Vol. 1
label: Quality Control
description: The Atlanta label home to Migos, Lil Yachty, and a squad of up-and-coming rappers showcases their year on top with a 30-song victory lap of minor-key flexers and foamy delights.

title: Too Hard
label: Quality Control
description: The Atlanta rapper is slowly coming into his own as a Young Thug disciple with an intrinsic tunefulness and strong storytelling that is marred by the undistinguished Quality Control production.

title: Improvisations
label: Care in the Community
description: There is chemistry between the Sonic Youth guitarist and the This Heat drummer, but their collaborative album feels more like mood pieces for skronk heads and completists only.

title: Habibi Funk: An Eclectic Selection of Music From the Arab World
label: Habibi Funk Records
description: A new compilation from Habibi Funk records highlights the old and interweaving sounds of Algerian coladera, Lebanese AOR, Egyptian disco, Moroccan funk and more.

title: Dedication
label: Glo Gang
description: Balancing his characteristic humor with newfound vulnerability, Keef’s latest is a worthy capstone to a prolific year in which the Chicago rapper has resurrected his reputation and career.

title: From a Room: Volume 1 / Volume 2
label: Mercury Nashville
description: Nashville institution Chris Stapleton followed his 2015 breakthrough with two new albums this year. They showcase his omnivorous approach to country music in all its dignified melancholy.

title: Perfect Lung
label: Halocline Trance
description: On his latest LP, the producer Ceramic TL (aka Egyptrixx) collaborates with Turkish composer Ipek Gorgun on another heady investigation of the global environmental crisis.

title: Daydream
label: Columbia
description: On 1995’s Daydream, the spectacular pop vocalist fine-tuned her songcraft. The album redrew the boundaries of what a Mariah Carey song—and a pop song—was supposed to sound like.

title: Lex
label: Rvng Intl.
description: Augmenting electro-acoustic fusions with speech synthesis and language translation software, Visible Cloaks invoke mystifying new form of dialects and communication on their mini-LP.

title: Book of Sound
label: Honest Jon's
description: On their latest album, the ensemble that made their name in scrappy performances on the sidewalks and street corners of New York City and Chicago turns muted, spare, warm and still.

title: KIMBERLY: The People I Used to Know
label: Atlantic
description: The singer, reality star, and social-media icon is joyous and defiant, projecting realness and flaunting considerable vocal chops.

title: Buy Corals Online
label: Editions Mego
description: The latest from Copenhagen’s Loke Rahbek—a collaboration with multimedia artist Frederik Valentin—is a set of wistful sketches for synthesizer and piano that gracefully sway.

title: Pender Street Steppers
label: Mood Hut
description: The new EP from Pender Street Steppers collects five tracks of the Vancouver duo’s breezy, hazy house music. It finds the Steppers not venturing very far outside of their comfort zone.

title: How to Solve Our Human Problems, Pt. 1
label: Matador
description: The first in a trio of new mini-albums from Belle and Sebastian finds the Glaswegian indie-pop greats speaking to our times. At its best, it grows into a divine six-minute prog-disco suite.

title: Kingdoms Disdained
label: Silver Lining
description: Morbid Angel’s ninth album sets the death metal band back on course. Featuring Trey Azagthoth’s molten solos, the band rediscover what they did well across their career and double down on it.

title: Squeeze Box: The Complete Works of “Weird Al” Yankovic
label: Legacy
description: The 15-disc box set of puns and polka is a monument to pop music’s once symbiotic relationship with parody—a linkage that has dissolved in the wake of the monoculture’s demise.

title: Catch These Vibes
label: Atlantic
description: On the young singer’s second major label album, PnB struggles to push past the boundaries of his previous work, but with a few solid tunes, it shows him finding his way in the major-label apparatus.

title: Or More; the Anxious
label: self-released
description: Chicago rapper Mick Jenkins’ new mixtape strikes the balance between hard-nosed spitting and the breezy consciousness of daisy-age-influenced acid rap.

title: No Shame
label: 300 Entertainment
description: On his corrosive fifth album, the rapper takes aim at several targets and whiffs spectacularly. His verbose, tryhard technique is a tired formula he employs without flow, direction, or meaning.

title: Weighing of the Heart
label: Ninja Tune
description: On her debut LP, British producer Nabihah Iqbal—fka Throwing Shade—has a rare touch with inky new wave synths and drum machines, emerging as a songwriter of impressive emotional heft.

title: Material Control
label: Globochem
description: On their first album in 15 years, the Long Island post-hardcore band Glassjaw picks up right where they left off. But their heaviest material yet is, at times, lacking in dynamics and atmosphere.

title: A.M./Being There
label: Rhino
description: Newly reissued and remastered, the group’s first two albums find Jeff Tweedy and his Chicago band transforming themselves from alt-country also-rans into a formidable rock‘n’roll outfit.

title: The Visitor
label: Reprise
description: While still pointedly political, Neil Young’s latest with Promise of the Real takes a more freewheeling, macro look at the world and becomes more centered than his recent albums.

title: Perfect Angel
label: Capitol
description: A deluxe reissue of Minnie Riperton’s best album—fusing funk, reggae, folk, soul—includes bonus tracks and new liner notes, which elaborate on the process of recording this classic with Stevie Wonder.

title: Everyday Is Christmas
label: RCA
description: Sia’s shiny Christmas album feels inconsistent and underwritten, like opening a gift where someone’s forgotten to remove the tags.

title: Zaytown Sorority Class of 2017
label: self-released
description: The prolific Atlanta producer enlists 17 women for an all-female mixtape that is well-intentioned and occasionally delightful, but doesn't have enough highlights to sustain its momentum.

title: Post Self
label: Avalanche
description: The new LP from pioneering industrial band Godflesh is the duo’s best effort in over 20 years—a sinister amalgam of Justin Broadrick and G.C. Green’s collective work to date.

title: Songs of Experience
label: Island
description: Years in the making, U2’s 14th studio album finds the band straining to reassert its relevance in a world where rock music has long since ceded its vanguard status.

title: Endless Computer
label: Nuclear War Now!
description: With their vicious debut LP, Austin quartet Expander ascend to the Texas thrash pantheon, evoking familiar metal-punk sounds as well as dystopian sci-fi themes.

title: cybersex
label: Beartrap
description: With a long bench of guests from 2 Chainz to Ne-Yo, the singer’s fourth album is sometimes catchy but astonishingly hollow and derivative.

title: Metal Machine Music
label: RCA
description: Lou Reed’s 1975 album has been called one of the worst albums ever made. The truth is it is the product of genuine love and passion, still exhilarating and bursting with possibility four decades on.

title: Master of Puppets
label: Blackened Recordings
description: In 1986, Metallica released inarguably one of the best metal records of all time. Newly remastered with live takes and demos, the album’s riffs, power, and mania remain as potent as ever.

title: Oblivion
label: RCA
description: T-Pain’s first studio album in six years cashes in on the good graces he’s received in the interim, but also retreads vastly familiar territory that is more fun than illuminating.

title: Loüm / Go Be Forgotten
label: self-released
description: New York City’s most consistent metallurgists offer a deliberate break from their past on their seventh and eighth albums. A decade into a prolific career, Krallice prove newly elusive.

title: Friday on Elm Street
label: Def Jam
description: On the New York rappers’ collaboration, just about every bar is sharply written, rapped, and also could’ve been plucked from any project these two have done in the 21st century.

title: Call Me By Your Name (Original Motion Picture Soundtrack)
label: Madison Gate
description: The soundtrack to Italian director Luca Guadagnino’s new film uses 1980s pop singles and classical pieces to help tell the deliriously romantic story of lovers Elio and Oliver.

title: Kick
label: Atlantic
description: The 30th-anniversary edition of Kick affirms its status as a jewel of ’80s pop-rock. It’s a showcase of the band’s opulent production, slithery grooves, and the allure of Michael Hutchence’s simplicity.

title: War & Leisure
label: Bystorm
description: Miguel’s fourth album has a kinetic sexual and political energy. With less digital funk and more reverbed-out guitar, his R&B psychedelia for uncertain times shows his maturation as a songwriter.

title: Polygondwanaland
label: ATO
description: Psych-rock band King Gizzard is giving its fourth album of the year away as a free download. The immersive Polygondwanaland is the farthest the seven-piece has strayed from its psych sci-fi roots.

title: Wopavelli 3
label: 1017 Eskimos
description: Lil Wop—the newest and most adamant Gucci Mane disciple—carves his own grotty, horrorcore path on his fourth mixtape of 2017, a wildly fun but sometimes rough listen.

title: Yes Lawd! Remixes
label: Stones Throw
description: On this collection of remixes from Anderson .Paak and Knxwledge’s 2016 LP, the latter artist flexes his mastery at deconstructing beats and samples—occasionally transforming the mood of a track.

title: Colón Man
label: DDS
description: The first proper LP from Equiknoxx is a clear step forward for the Kingston-based digital dancehall duo. Its textures leap from the speakers; the sound design is more vivid than ever.

title: Rainbow Mirror
label: Hospital Productions
description: Commemorating 20 years of his Prurient alias, Dominick Fernow’s sprawling, three-hour foray into “doom electronics” feels like a swing of the pendulum back to the noise project’s Rust Belt roots.

title: Plant Age
label: L.I.E.S.
description: On his debut album, the L.I.E.S. mainstay makes house music that’s dubby and lo-fi, like club tracks heard through a pillow.

title: The Greatest Gift
label: Asthmatic Kitty
description: Though too scattered to stand alone, the various demos and remixes culled from Carrie & Lowell add new context and dimension to Sufjan Stevens’ masterful album.

title: Blue Lips
label: Island
description: Of a piece with last year’s Lady Wood, the Swedish pop singer’s new album chronicles the death of a doomed, passionate love affair. It makes a powerful statement about female sexuality in the process.

label: Terrible
description: Sam Gendel’s smoothly psychedelic debut is dominated by the guitarist and saxophonist’s tip-toed melodies and hushed voice.

title: Who Built the Moon?
label: Sour Mash
description: Noel Gallagher’s latest is the most ambitious of his solo releases, internalizing the heyday of late ’90s Britpop while sounding both urgent and absurd to mostly great effect.

title: Fete Des Morts AKA Dia De Los Muertos EP
label: self-released
description: New Jersey’s Mach-Hommy is one of the East coast’s finest working rappers. Building on his cryptic mystique, his latest effort finds him diving into a collection of beats by Earl Sweatshirt.

title: بس ربحت, خسرت “When You Have Won, You Have Lost”
label: Toxic State
description: Atop imposing hardcore, the New York group’s Lebanese-American vocalist tackles politics, identity, and the complexity of his Shia Muslim upbringing.

title: Mount Qaf (Divine Love)
label: Fortune Tellers
description: Peter Matthew Bauer, bassist and organist in the Walkmen, fuses Eastern spirituality with the sound of heartland rock on his latest solo album.

title: No Dope on Sundays
label: Sony
description: After serving as one of the key writers in G.O.O.D. Music, CyHi’s thoroughly slick debut album finally arrives, with features from Kanye, Pusha T, Schoolboy Q, Travis Scott, and many more.

title: All Belief Is Paradise
label: Father/Daughter
description: The debut from pop-punk band Fits is full of sharp turns, heavy lyrics, and bursts of righteous anger. A fierce will to survive animates these lean, scrappy songs.

title: Utopia
label: One Little Indian
description: Filled with flute and birdsong, Björk’s 10th album is deeply personal, a discovery of googly-eyed romance, a rebuke of violent men, and a generous offering of love song after love song.

title: Memory of a Cut Off Head
label: Castle Face
description: The 20th LP from OCS—better known as Thee Oh Sees—is a softer and slower strand of psychedelia than the San Francisco garage-rock institution has come to be known for.

title: The Age of Consent
label: London
description: Featuring the groundbreaking pop hits ”Smalltown Boy” and “Why,” the 1984 debut album from the British synth-pop group was a transgressive moment—defiant, queer, and full of hooks.

title: Radio Silence
label: 3D
description: On his eighth solo album, Talib Kweli remains the vanguard for deep-thinking conscious rap; storytelling and uplift are in ample supply, though the risks are few and far between.

title: Soul of a Woman
label: Daptone
description: On her final, posthumously released album, Jones alternates powerful ballads with the upbeat dance numbers that were staples of her live shows, confirming her stature a contemporary soul-music icon.

title: The Fall - Singles 1978-2016
label: Cherry Red
description: This new seven-disc Fall box set surveys every single and B-side the Mancunian institution has released since 1978. It provides a tidy, linear history of a notoriously unstable band.

title: The Program
label: Killa Entertainment
description: On Cam’ron’s first full-length album in four years, he sounds disengaged. The beats don’t pop and the fun has drained from his lyrics.

title: Too Dumb for Suicide: Tim Heidecker’s Trump Songs
label: Jagjaguwar
description: A comedian known for his absurdity and irony, Tim Heidecker returns with an album of protest art as musical comedy. Its shining moments come when he is honest about his fear and anger over Trump’s regime.

title: FILM
label: self-released
description: Originally composed for a pair of soundtracks, Qasim Naqvi’s expressive new LP toggles between pure electronic sound design and minimalist composition.

title: Bill Brewster Presents Tribal Rites
label: Eskimo
description: A sort of biography in mixtape form, Tribal Rites offers the chance to hear dance-music history through the ears of one of the culture’s most discerning listeners.

title: Low in High School
label: BMG
description: Though the music is often engaging and exciting, Low in High School is Morrissey’s second consecutive release that feels regrettably tethered to his increasingly alienating public persona.

title: SYRE
label: Roc Nation
description: Full of chaotic beats and cringe-worthy lyrics, the debut studio album from Jaden Smith is a paranoid fantasy that mixes new age thinking with apocalyptic rhetoric.

title: Romaplasm
label: Anticon
description: On the latest Baths album, Will Wiesenfeld launches his beats and synths into the realm of vibrant fantasy. Of all his releases, it’s the one most rife with pure pleasure.

title: Bajas Fresh
label: Drag City
description: Over seven tracks that span 80 minutes, the expansive, looping, shifting synths and rhythms of Bajas Fresh mark the trio’s most diverse and ambitious record.

title: S/T
label: Saddle Creek
description: Literary, emotional, and filling up all the space between indie and post-rock, the Los Angeles band’s third album is not a conversation piece, but a dialogue meant to be shared.

title: Gifts From the Ebb Tide
label: YK
description: The third studio album from Coupler lays out ambient music that is hyper-specific, detailed, and undemanding.

title: Red Headed Stranger
label: Columbia
description: In 1975, Willie Nelson changed the rules of country music. His lonesome, noir concept album about a wayward preacher was a big and beautiful dream made real by simple and spare music.

title: Contributors
label: Monofonus
description: The new collaboration between the prolific Dan Melchior and Austin’s Spray Paint make mountains out of mantras across a jammy, post-punk album that barrels like an 18-wheeler down the highway.

title: This Trip
label: Vibe Over Method
description: On her debut album, Montreal visual artist-turned-electronic pop provocateur Alexandra Mackenzie makes vital protest music that summons collective strength to overcome existential fear.

title: Wasps’ Nests
label: Captured Tracks
description: In 1995, Stephin Merritt released a major-label synth-pop LP as the 6ths. He wrote all the songs but enlisted others to sing them, including Lou Barlow, Dean Wareham, Georgia Hubley, and Mary Timony.

title: Horse Blanket
label: self-released
description: The Seattle indie rock band’s final record is a great parting gift, one with generous portions of wit, melancholy, and even one long guitar solo.

title: Summer Megalith
label: Flower Girl
description: The debut album from Caracara—co-produced by former Modern Baseball frontman Jacob Ewald—is dynamic and diffuse, drawing on slowcore, gothic folk, post-hardcore, and more.

title: Air Lows
label: Blackest Ever Black
description: The fifth full-length from the experimental Berlin-based musician offers a meditation on negativity that’s dreary and enervating in equal turns.

title: Rest
label: Because
description: Sung mostly in French, Gainsbourg’s gripping new album finds her in the tangles of grief. It is at once scorchingly intimate and fantastically oversized.

title: Introduce Yerself
label: Arts & Crafts
description: Recorded in his final months and released 10 days after his death, the Tragically Hip frontman’s final album is a farewell and a testament, at once wistful and playful, urgent and defiantly hopeful.

title: Ascending a Mountain of Heavy Light
label: Thrill Jockey
description: The second collaboration between the two experimental metal bands feels necessary. They bands flood the gap between doom and grindcore with all kinds of stunts, risks, and tricks.

title: New Shapes of Life
label: Tapete
description: The Boo Radleys mastermind returns with a suave, sophisticated, rhythmically robust pop record whose swagger belies deep-seated feelings of disillusionment, self-doubt, and paranoia.

title: The Mustard Seed
label: Six5
description: The St. Paul rapper’s latest album is a study in faith and focus. His acrobatic rapping, rich hooks, and warm textures create a soulful record full of high stakes and interior depth.

title: If All I Was Was Black
label: Anti-
description: Mavis Staples presents her signature hope on the taut and lively If All I Was Was Black, another collaboration with Jeff Tweedy. But it doesn’t come as naturally as it once did, as she makes clear.

title: Laugh Now, Fly Later
label: Atlantic
description: Across a relatively lean, stakes-free mixtape, Wiz Khalifa riffs on his only meaningful muse, weed, with a level of buy-in that he rarely grants his commercial projects.

title: Interiors
label: Epitaph
description: The first album in 22 years from seminal New York post-hardcore band Quicksand is a structurally-obsessed work where beauty and brutality coexist.

title: Out of Range
label: Paradise of Bachelors
description: Now relocated to Los Angeles, the five-piece moves comfortably into breezy, slow-going, cosmic country as both an escape and a protest.

title: Music for Nine Postcards
label: Empire of Signs
description: Inspired by a series of window views, Japanese ambient pioneer Hiroshi Yoshimura’s 1982 album Music for Nine Postcards has a disarming presence, cutting sweetly into the listener’s reality.

title: No Luscious Life
label: Golden Teacher
description: The Glasgow sextet brings a healthy dose of dub to its spiky punk-acid-disco fusion, to party-starting (and occasionally political) effect.

title: Snapshot
label: self-released
description: The debut long-player from UK funky pioneer Reiss Hanson, aka Champion, is high-energy bass music as bare-knuckled pointillism. His recordings have rarely sounded more dynamic or more colorful.

title: Birdie
label: Lame-O
description: With the second album from his Slaughter Beach, Dog project, Jake Ewald of Modern Baseball has found his voice as a musician, though he’s still searching as a writer.

title: Automatic for the People
label: Craft
description: In 1992, R.E.M. were the biggest, most important rock band in America. This reissue of their multi-platinum smash, 25 years later, highlights a brooding, transitional album that still resonates.

title: Mnestic Pressure
label: Hyperdub
description: Navigating the divide between club culture and conceptual art, the UK producer repurposes the momentum-based language of dance music into a hauntingly frozen inversion.

title: ROME
label: Backwoodz Studioz
description: Brooklyn emcees Elucid and Billy Woods’ third album as Armand Hammer is a stellar underground hip-hop record. They are radical and full of heart, delivering cocksure homilies from the margins of rap.

title: Before I Wake
label: self-released
description: On the first of two mixtapes to be released before her major label debut, Before I Wake finds the Oakland emcee less relaxed and laidback. It plays out like a reassertion of control.

title: Reputation
label: Big Machine
description: Taylor Swift’s sixth album is an aggressive, lascivious display of craftsmanship, but her full embrace of modern pop feels sadly conventional.

title: Chelsea Girl
label: Verve
description: On her 1967 debut album, Nico’s unmistakable voice sings the songs of Bob Dylan, Lou Reed, and Jackson Browne. Chelsea Girl helps define her as a mercurial aura and a manifold, complicated artist.

title: U-Men
label: Sub Pop
description: The Seattle band U-Men released only one full-length during their eight-year run in the 1980s, but their legend loomed large over a generation. A new Sub Pop reissue collects their crucial catalog.

title: Hesaitix
label: Pan
description: With Hesaitix, the Berlin-based DJ and producer has built a strange world that lives and breathes. It’s a catchy, fascinating electronic album that lives in a lucid unreality.

title: Stranger
label: YEAR0001
description: The Swedish rapper’s third album offers glimpses of his full potential, songs that pierce through the detachment that once obscured real emotion.

title: Rot
label: What's Your Rupture?
description: On the follow-up to their 2013 debut LP, the beer-swilling, self-described former “party band” grows up without slowing down.

title: Tauhid/Jewels of Thought/Deaf Dumb Blind (Summun Bukmun Umyun)
label: Anthology Recordings
description: Three invaluable reissues showcase a young bandleader and his top-tier players as they create a powerfully cohesive group sound: elegant, adventurous, warm, and ferocious all at once.

title: Arpo
label: Houndstooth
description: The second album from producer Joe Seaton offers a rush of effervescence. With a childlike and immersive touch, he pulls apart and rearranges small, twinkling sounds.

title: Phases
label: Jagjaguwar
description: This collection of B-sides, demos, and covers is terrific and revelatory in its own right. It's a trail of dropped clues to the creative process of the defiantly mercurial Olsen.

title: Les Fleurs Du Mal
label: Halcyon Veil
description: Eric Burton’s latest album is a logical extension of his to 2015 album Communion,  an experimental world of dissolving certainty where all light is gradually leached out of the landscape.

title: The 1st
label: MSFTS MUSIC
description: With her second album, Willow Smith opts for a more organic and raw sound. It’s a huge leap in the right direction, as she uses her guitar to channel alternative singer-songwriters of the 1990s.

title: Backwater
label: Ghostly International
description: The Australian duo’s debut full length features warm, pleasing vocal lines and electro-pop beats, but it never coheres to tell the kind of story they want to tell.

title: Kid Kruschev
label: Torn Clean
description: Like everyone else, Sleigh Bells are feeling the weight of the world in 2017. Their lean new mini-album has more thematic cohesion than their previous releases and also a surprising tenderness.

title: Vante EP
label: Urban Scandal
description: Christopher Owens, formerly of Girls, calls Curls—a trio with drummer Cody Rhodes and bassist Luke Baće—his first “real band.” Their new EP contains some of the most lavish-sounding music he has released.

title: Red Pill Blues
label: Interscope
description: Adam Levine’s band return for their sixth album of smooth, professional, antiseptic soft-rock, which somehow also features Kendrick Lamar, Future, and A$AP Rocky.

title: Noir et Blanc
label: Crammed Discs
description: Released in 1983, Noir et Blanc still sounds like a broadcast from the future—the influential work of Congolese and French musicians using analog synths, strange effects, and stranger time signatures.

title: The Animal Spirits
label: Border Community
description: Electronic producer James Holden has remade himself into a bandleader on his new album—a collection of self-described “folk-trance” recorded with improv ensemble the Animal Spirits.

title: Anthropocene
label: Western Vinyl
description: The restless singer-songwriter’s wanderlust leads him to find poetic beauty in the country’s ugly truths, even as he confronts the idea that there’s more at stake than ever.

title: EP2
label: Godmode
description: The music of New York producer Yaeji—part house, part hip-hop—hints at strong feelings with subtle tones. On her second EP, she pushes her sound further to its poles.

title: Time Spent Away From U
label: Lobster Fury
description: Behind DJ Seinfeld’s resolutely non-serious façade lies a strikingly wistful take on deep house. His debut LP pushes even further in this direction.

title: The Thrill of It All
label: Capitol
description: The second album from the pop crooner uses the same method that made his debut such a commercial success. His spectacular voice doles out feelings in terms everyone can understand.

title: Do You Mind EP
label: Luft
description: On their ethereal debut EP, the Norwegian electro-pop trio treat romance with a stylish, if sometimes frustrating, remove.

title: Tokorats
label: Stones Throw
description: The new album from Jonti—a part-time touring guitarist for the Avalanches—is aesthetically omnivorous, encompassing dream pop, electronica, hip-hop, and R&B. It sounds unrestrained and overproduced.

title: Have You Been There, Have You Seen It EP
label: Ninja Tune
description: The Hamburg DJ applies the energy of her spine-tingling DJ sets to a suggestively lo-fi set of acid-soaked electro-techno jams.

title: MILANO
label: 30th Century
description: The Italian composer recruits Parquet Courts and Karen O to pay tribute to the Italian city’s hedonistic 1980s heyday.

title: Savage Young Dü
label: Numero Group
description: After decades of legal red tape and intraband strife, Minneapolis’ revolutionary punk trio break the silence with an exhaustive summary of their lo-fi, frenetic first three years.

title: Fumbling Towards Ecstasy
label: Nettwerk
description: The Canadian singer-songwriter’s third record is a fascinating outlier in her catalog, an unsparing and expansive album written in the mountains of Quebec following traumatic experiences in her life.

title: Bay Head
label: Three Lobed
description: Steve Gunn and John Truscinski’s third album of low-key, abstract jams is their most varied and narratively absorbing to date.

title: Fragments of a Season
label: Emotional Rescue
description: Two ambient-leaning auteurs unite for a charming exercise in bright guitar tones and wistful moods, rooted in their mutual admiration for Manchester legend Vini Reilly.

title: Phantom Brickworks
label: Warp
description: The restless UK electronic musician sets aside prior experiments in spliced soul and finger-picking folk-glitch in favor of foggy ambient atmospheres that are both soothing and haunting.

title: Trouble No More: The Bootleg Series Vol. 13 / 1979-1981
label: Columbia Legacy
description: The latest installment of the Bootleg Series excavates live recordings and demos from Dylan’s infamous, fruitful, and polarizing era as an evangelical Christian.

title: Without Warning
label: Slaughter Gang
description: The two rappers and producer strike a devious, almost perfect balance on their mixtape released on Halloween, where supernatural frights are replaced by guns and goons.

title: Revelations
label: Father/Daughter
description: Shamir Bailey’s latest is a lo-fi set of interesting ideas that never quite gel. As ever, his soulful voice is the star, offering hints of sophistication and wonder.

title: Jolly New Songs
label: Blue Tapes
description: On their nimble new LP, the Polish quartet Trupa Trupa bring some poetry and subtlety to psychedelic rock.

title: Superlative Fatigue
label: Pan
description: Erik Wiegand produced his wildly fun new record with the digital synth he invented. Fueled by dancehall, its manic pleasure offers a way out of techno’s self-serious cul-de-sac.

title: Under the Western Freeway
label: Friendship Fever
description: It’s been a sad year for these early-2000s indie-rock heroes, but this reissue of their cult-classic 1997 debut is a reminder that Grandaddy was a special band from the start.

title: I Still Am
label: Epic
description: The new album from Yo Gotti—current ambassador of Memphis rap—digs deeper into his roles as struggler, hustler, and city spokesman, with a more pointed focus on betrayal.

title: Value
label: Big Dada
description: The London producer’s latest full-length, a high-concept electronic consideration of the artistic soul, balances between fragility and bombast.

title: The Dusk in Us
label: Epitaph
description: The ninth album from the metalcore architects is sharp and urgent. Jacob Bannon’s songwriting shines as he turns his back on interpersonal torment and faces something bigger and more existential.

title: No Pop
label: Felte
description: On their fourth album, the restless Toronto trio change lanes again, this time to minimal, claustrophobic electronic music that sounds like the end of the world.

title: Beach House 3
label: Atlantic
description: Ty Dolla $ign’s new album is superbly refined. It leverages his gravelly voice, attention to detail, and willingness to kill his ego.

title: The Space Between
label: OVO Sound
description: The refined sophomore album from Majid Jordan—best known for featuring on Drake’s “Hold On, We’re Going Home”—finds the Toronto duo coasting on an atmospheric pop-R&B sound that is uniquely their own.

title: Stranger Things 2 (A Netflix Original Series Soundtrack)
label: Lakeshore
description: The heady electronic duo that gave Netflix’s sci-fi success story its signature sound are back for another round, with plenty of nostalgia and some new tricks.

title: Static Age
label: Caroline
description: Recorded in 1978 and shelved for two decades, what should have been the band’s London Calling befuddled record execs who didn’t know what to do with a B-movie-obsessed punk with an Elvis croon.

title: Walk Among Us
label: Ruby Records
description: They were outliers when they started, but by the time their classic debut arrived in 1982, Misfits’ gleeful, ghoulish punk rock was exactly in tune with the national mood.

title: Danzig III: How the Gods Kill
label: Def American
description: On the third album he made with his biggest band, Glenn Danzig lived up to his larger-than-life metal-god myth in ways he’s rarely done since.

title: Danzig
label: Def American
description: Glenn Danzig’s first eponymous album was a thunderous, Rick Rubin-produced progression of his moody, Evil Elvis sound. It’s the pinnacle of goth populism.

title: 4eva Is a Mighty Long Time
label: Multi Alumni
description: Big K.R.I.T. is at the top of his game on his new double album. It’s an even split between booming subwoofers and tough-guy talk on one side and a considerable vulnerability on the other.

title: Mirror Reaper
label: Profound Lore
description: Seattle doom metal duo Bell Witch’s third album sounds broken down by life and death alike, but it scrapes together something like hope.

title: All American Made
label: Third Man
description: On her second album, one of Nashville’s biggest new stars ups the ante with a stark survey of a country in crisis.

title: Plunge
label: Rabid
description: On her second album as Fever Ray, Karin Dreijer is more conflicted, more manic—and more in love, too.

title: Punk Drunk and Trembling EP
label: Domino
description: A month after calling it quits, the inventive British art-rockers bid farewell with a revealing EP drawn from the sessions for their final album.

title: I Can Hear the Heart Beating as One
label: Matador
description: Twenty years on from its original release, Yo La Tengo’s finest album still sparkles with wit and charm, an album so cozy you forget about its musical eclecticism.

title: Joli Mai
label: Jialong
description: Dan Snaith’s new LP as Daphni contains unmixed, extended versions of many of the tracks from his recent Fabriclive 93 mix. Some tracks falter in the context of an album, but others flower in new ways.

title: Sonder Son
label: Lost Kids
description: On his heartfelt new album, R&B upstart Brent Faiyaz finds joy in the midst of struggle. He works through his pain without kowtowing to radio trends, offering a promising debut.

title: Screen Memories
label: Ribbon Music
description: The latest collection from synth-pop retrofuturist and punk intellectual John Maus contains grander, darker songs than his previous albums. It’s a thrill to encounter his singular voice.

title: Thinking Out Loud
label: Paper Route Empire
description: After two attempts on his life in seven months, the rapper Young Dolph has simply gotten back to work. His latest is a brisk, blunt album with tremendous features from Gucci Mane and 2 Chainz.

title: A flame my love, a frequency
label: Thrill Jockey
description: French artist Cécile Schott wrote her new LP as Colleen—an electronic reflection on mortality—in the wake of the 2015 Paris terrorist attacks. Despite the heavy themes, her sound is lighter than ever.

title: Play the Songs You Like
label: Salinas
description: One of the hardest-working singers in indie-pop returns to his main band for their first full-length since 2014’s breakthrough Torch Song.

title: Needle Paw
label: Sony
description: On her solo debut, Nai Palm abandons her band Hiatus Kaiyote’s expansive future-soul aesthetic in favor of acoustic intimacy; it is, above all, a testament to the power of the voice.

title: Turn Out the Lights
label: Matador
description: The second album from Tennessee songwriter Julien Baker wrestles with self-worth, rejection, and God. Centering on her voice, guitar, and piano, Baker begins to sound defiant.

title: The Best of Both Worlds
label: Classic Music Company
description: A glorious vision of house music’s inclusive, utopian potential unfolds on this DJ and producer’s first full-length album.

title: Ogilala
label: BMG
description: In his latest reinvention, the Smashing Pumpkins frontman hires Rick Rubin to deliver a prestige comeback album in the producer’s usual stripped-down and soul-baring mode—but Corgan is no Johnny Cash.

title: Listen Without Prejudice Vol. 1
label: Sony
description: On a new four-disc reissue of George Michael’s mostly acoustic, bossa nova-inflected LP from 1990, the pleasures of the flesh co-exist with a deepening spiritual malaise.

title: Pacific Daydream
label: Crush
description: On their 11th album, Rivers Cuomo and co. aim for a hook-filled tribute to California guitar pop but the production gloss suffocates any personality these songs could have had.

title: It’s Alright Between Us as It Is
label: Smalltown Supersound
description: The Norwegian producer Hans-Peter Lindstrøm’s latest solo full-length feels breezily noncommittal. Each experiment—including a spoken word piece by Jenny Hval—dissolves into the next.

title: Tokyo Flashback
label: Black Editions
description: A new reissue of this influential 1991 Japanese psych compilation—with gems from Ghost, Keiji Haino and others—is a revelatory listen.

title: CCFX EP
label: DFA
description: CCFX is the filmic dream pop collaboration of Mary Jane Dunphe (Vexx, CC Dust) and members of Olympia band Trans FX. Their EP for DFA Records is brought to life by Dunphe’s visceral, magnetic vocals.

title: Any Other Way
label: Numero Group
description: A new box set documents the riveting story of Toronto soul singer and transgender music pioneer Jackie Shane. Hers are songs laced with pain but emboldened by a remarkable sense of self-possession.

title: Going Grey
label: Fueled by Ramen
description: The New Jersey-based indie-rock underdogs, more popular than ever before, embrace synths on their sixth studio album.

title: Death Revenge
label: Relapse
description: The goregrind crew’s sixth album, based on a 19th-century Scottish killing spree, is the metal equivalent of a bingeable British TV period piece.

title: Losing
label: Sub Pop
description: Singer-guitarist Alicia Bognanno sounds tensed and ready to strike on the Nashville-based grunge torchbearers’ second album (and first for Sub Pop).

title: Super Slimey
label: Epic
description: This surprise-released collaboration sees the Atlanta rappers finally finding common ground, though neither is in peak form. Super Slimey forgoes explosiveness and poignancy for streamlined action.

title: Musik
label: Secretly Canadian
description: On a new collection of recordings stowed away since the 1980s, the iconic color photographer extends his knack for defamiliarizing the mundane to synthesizers and pop standards.

title: Glasshouse
label: Island
description: On her third album, the English singer/songwriter vividly captures a love both intimate and powerful.

title: Thawing Dawn
label: Dull Tools
