description: The debut solo LP from Andrew Savage of Parquet Courts finds him singing more intimately about love in quieter, more rustic settings. In its own peculiar way, it speaks to our current condition.

title: III
label: Run for Cover
description: Soaring Swedish indie rockers Makthaverskan deliver anthems of heartache that anyone could love on their third album.

title: Anthology: Movie Themes 1974-1998
label: Sacred Bones
description: New recordings of the horror auteur’s iconic film themes, from Halloween to Assault on Precinct 13 and beyond, highlight his influential approach to music.

title: The Queen Is Dead
label: Warner Bros.
description: Newly reissued as a boxed set, the Smiths’ 1986 masterpiece still stands as an enduring testament to England in the ’80s, the complex relationship between performer and fan, and the ecstasy of emptiness.

title: The Saga Continues
label: Entertainment One
description: Thanks to Martin Shkreli, Wu-Tang is worth millions again. But is their new album even worth your time?

title: Beginning to Fall in Line Before Me, So Decorously, the Nature of All That Must Be Transformed
label: W.25TH
description: A new live album from the avant-garde power trio led by Japanese noise icon Keiji Haino is a demented joy, best experienced at high volumes.

title: Sis-boom-bah!
label: Dekmantel
description: The Israeli-Dutch techno duo’s fifth album is an intriguing left turn, leading them far from the dancefloor and well into serene, spacey new age territory.

title: Ruler Rebel / Diaspora / The Emancipation Procrastination
label: Ropeadope
description: On the three albums that compose The Centennial Trilogy, the New Orleans horn player and composer pays tribute to the American jazz tradition by tapping into the legacy of fusion.

title: Humble Beast
label: Machine Entertainment Group
description: The Chicago rapper has earned his role as a leader of rap. His latest album recalls the best records of the ’00s graced with a singular kind of songwriting that sounds inarguably like the present.

title: In the City / This Is the Modern World / The Polydor Demos: February 1977 / Live 1977 + John Peel Sessions
label: UME
description: Their career was just beginning, but the Jam were already the hardest-working band in U.K. punk. A new box set revisits their breakthrough year.

title: ken
label: Merge
description: Elegant and perverse, Dan Bejar’s latest album slinks around in the shadows like he did on Kaputt, synthy, sleazy, and newly paranoid. He remains one of the most evocative songwriters of his generation.

title: Reaching for Indigo
label: Drag City
description: Haley Fohr’s latest and best record of experimental folk folds in some of the simpler songwriting of her countrified Jackie Lynn project.

title: As You Please
label: Run for Cover
description: The Ohio rock band’s bleak, heavy, and ambitious third LP is a subtle signal that they’re a band their fans can grow up with rather than out of.

title: The Con X: Covers
label: Warner Bros.
description: Tegan and Sara are celebrating the 10th anniversary of their vanguard fifth album with a compilation of covers from Hayley Williams, Chvrches, Bleachers, Grimes, Kelly Lee Owens, and more.

title: Mr. Davis
label: Atlantic
description: Seventeen months since his release from prison, Gucci Mane delivers one of his most consistent and accessible releases in years, and a prime showcase for his renewed charisma.

title: D.K. / S.K. EP
label: Melody As Truth
description: The first collaboration from increasingly-mellow producers Diego Herrera (aka Suzanne Kraft) and Dang-Khoa Chau wades into sedate territory that’s tentative but promising.

title: Ain’t Too Long
label: self-released
description: On his third mixtape this year, the young Baton Rouge rapper continues to upend the fear and survivalism that he carries with him.

title: Body Consonance
label: Hands in the Dark
description: In a departure from the spatial concerns of his site-specific pieces, the composer’s new album explores the physicality of sound itself.

title: Morning After
label: OVO Sound
description: The second album from the OVO R&B duo wades into the thick fog of heartbreak but stays grounded by the delicate and powerful voice of Daniel Daley and the shadowy, cinematic beats of Ninteen85.

title: Wamp 2 Dem
label: Island
description: With top-shelf beats and assists from A-list contributors, the South London rapper’s new mixtape aims to show American listeners that there’s more to British rap than grime and cameos on Drake singles.

title: Lune Rouge
label: Young Art
description: The Los Angeles electronic musician rebounds from a rare brain disease—and the temporary loss of her ability to speak and hear music—by confidently streamlining her pop impulses.

title: Rose
label: Ninja Tune
description: For her debut album, now reissued on vinyl by Ninja Tune, Abra draws on the cynicism of darkwave and its brooding hues, while making room for brighter beats, quicker tempos, and lyrical vulnerability.

title: Colors
label: Fonograf
description: Beck’s 13th album is his most overtly pop record, one filled with sunshine and sadness, but feels connected to little more than a good idea.

title: There Is No Love in Fluorescent Light
label: Last Gang
description: The Montreal indie band Stars have stretched hushed electro-pop into scrambling arena rock for nearly 20 years. They sound revived and more emotionally mature on their eighth album.

title: Murderburgers
label: Khannibalism
description: The once wildly unhinged psych-rock maverick grows into adulthood, though his backing band brings some much-needed weirdness to the proceedings.

title: A Love Letter to You 2
label: Capitol
description: Ohio rapper Trippie Redd’s second mixtape this year is all hooks, all emotion, but features poorly designed songs that lack the spark of his previous mixtape.

title: The Magic City / My Brother the Wind Vol. 1
label: Cosmic Myth
description: Sun Ra manifested an ecstatic vision of jazz that is still being unpacked and realized a half-century on. A pair of new reissues highlight two defining albums in his oeuvre.

title: Masseduction
label: Loma Vista
description: Annie Clark’s fifth album as St. Vincent isn’t a pop album so much as a deeply, admittedly personal communique with a pop veneer. The songs tear into the feeling of leaving and having been left alone.

title: Wrong Way Up
label: Opal
description: Brian Eno and John Cale’s 1990 collaboration is an album of contention, contrasts, cycles, and pop songs so layered and euphoric it is one of the best albums either artist has ever made.

title: For Paris
label: Novel Sound
description: Though weighted with a complicated backstory, Vincent’s latest album contains some of the most organic and sincere techno to come out this year.

title: Exit Entrance
label: DFA
description: Japan’s Kouhei Matsunaga, aka NHK yx koyxen, takes a scientific approach to experimental electronic music. His new album is a dynamic work of maze-like rhythms, trapdoors, and serenity.

title: Eros in Arabia
label: Freedom to Spend
description: On his 1981 debut album, the composer and percussionist channels the Fourth World spirit of his collaborator Jon Hassell, to spellbinding effect.

title: Offering
label: Sinderlyn
description: On the third album from the bedroom-pop duo, Madeline Follin and Brian Oblivion turn their faces toward the sun with songs fuller and brighter than ever before.

title: Nothing Valley
label: Wax Nine
description: On their debut album, the quartet applies noise-rock chops and jazz-versed drumming to a wild set of songs with a gastrointestinal fixation.

title: The OOZ
label: True Panther
description: The producer born Archy Marshall crafted The OOZ to be alien and timeless. It is the richest and most immersive album the London singer-songwriter has made yet, under any name.

title: Shaneera EP
label: Hyperdub
description: Producer Fatima Al Qadiri adapts the “evil extreme femme alter ego” of Shaneera for her new EP on the Hyperdub label, which is packed with melody, drama, and joy.

title: Wide Open
label: Kanine
description: The new LP from Toronto’s Weaves features more refined production than their 2016 debut. It highlights frontwoman Jasmyn Burke’s lyrics about personal experiences that parlay into universal struggle.

title: Tenderness
label: Arbutus
description: Raphaelle Standell and Alexander Kerby’s third album draws upon classic house and disco in its examination of the pitfalls of love in the digital era.

title: Lil Pump
label: Tha Lights Global
description: Lil Pump’s debut is loud, hyper, and catchy. There isn’t a moment where the 17-year-old rapper, seemingly born in some viral think tank, doesn’t sound completely, endearingly stoked.

title: Pinewood Smile
label: Cooking Vinyl
description: The Darkness have never sounded more dated, or more like unsuccessful comedy rock, than on their depressing new album.

title: Lotta Sea Lice
label: Matador
description: The collaborative LP from Kurt Vile and Courtney Barnett feels like an overheard discussion between two existential misfits. They sing songs about writing songs, covering each other in the process.

title: DEADSTAR
label: Alamo
description: On his debut album, the 20-year-old Florida rapper offers a dead-eyed approximation of the SoundCloud rap zeitgeist; it’s an album full of undirected transgressions, less thrilling than numbing.

title: Cry Cry Cry
label: Sub Pop
description: Wolf Parade have cleaned up further on their streamlined new record, making for solid throwback indie rock.

title: Three Futures
label: 4AD
description: The new album from singer-songwriter Mackenzie Scott is her most ambitious work by an order of magnitude. It’s an electric-electronic hybrid that is lush, physical, and full of contradictions.

title: Heaven Upside Down
label: Loma Vista
description: On his 10th album, Marilyn Manson embraces the tropes that made him a menace and a rock star and a stalwart of goth. This is his turf, and rather than expand it, he seeks to defend it.

title: Damn the Torpedoes
label: Backstreet
description: Damn the Torpedos is the peak of Tom Petty’s songwriting with the Heartbreakers. Slick, big, and immutably classic, the album is a front-to-back feat of production and songwriting.

title: Wildflowers
label: Warner Bros.
description: When he was 44 years old, Tom Petty released his second and greatest solo album. It is a crucial entry to his catalog, one whose songwriting is elegantly spare, personal, and intuitive.

title: Full Moon Fever
label: MCA
description: On his debut solo album, Tom Petty’s economical, thoughtful songwriting gelled with Jeff Lynne’s restrained production. They crafted a laid-back sound but kept the tension of heartland rock‘n’roll.

title: Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers
label: Shelter
description: Despite featuring two of the band’s most enduring hits, Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers’ debut is best remembered as a sketchpad for ideas that came together later.

title: Belief System
label: Houndstooth
description: Amplifying the scope of his rave-nostalgia project, Paul Woolford expands his ambitions but loses sight of the spontaneity that made the music so thrilling in the first place.

title: Fatherland
label: BMG
description: On his third solo album, the former Bloc Party frontman unexpectedly trades electronic trappings for a folksy, fingerpicked inner-soul audit.

title: The Weather Station
label: Paradise of Bachelors
description: Toronto songwriter Tamara Lindeman self-produced her bold fourth LP. From front-to-back, this is the first Weather Station album that sounds as fleshed-out and powerful as the world it contains.

title: I Love You Like a Brother
label: Dead Oceans
description: On her giddy rush of a debut, Australia’s Alex Lahey offers a remarkably focused set of sing-along choruses, punk-pop dynamics, and casually witty observations about relationships.

title: For Sale: Live at Maxwell’s 1986
label: Rhino
description: This oft-bootlegged, now greatly enhanced 29-song recording finds the Replacements on the brink of a crucial turning point—like a final college bender before entering the working world.

title: The Carnival
label: Columbia
description: Riding the wave of success from the Fugees’ The Score, Wyclef Jean’s 1997 solo debut is a 74-minute party, as advertised. It’s a proud transcultural product that broadcasted an eclectic future.

title: Dreams and Daggers
label: Mack Avenue
description: The young jazz singer’s live double album showcases the gravitas, humor, and modernity she brings both to classic standards and her own compositions.

title: U Feel Anything?
label: Planet Mu
description: In her abraded experimental club music, Berlin producer Ziúr favors a skeletal sound that still confidently occupies a maximal amount of space. It suggests that agitation can produce beauty.

title: Red Burns
label: Grand Closing
description: Standing on the Corner is the collaboration of two jazz-inclined oddballs from New York City. Their dazzling, invigorating Red Burns project is a freeform response to recent world events.

title: Electric Circus
label: Vinyl Me Please
description: Newly reissued on vinyl, Common’s 2002 album is a massive group effort: Prince, Erykah Badu, Pharrell, Jill Scott, and many more built a sound that helped change the limits of rap, soul, and R&B.

title: Take Me Apart
label: Warp
description: Kelela’s debut album is technically stunning and emotionally realized. It lives in a new, outré, rhythmic pop galaxy that honors but outpaces its peers.

title: Josie and the Pussycats—Music from the Motion Picture
label: Mondo
description: The first reissue of the 2001 film’s soundtrack proves the last legacy of three Archie comics characters.

title: Eternal Recurrence
label: Anticon
description: Angel Deradoorian zooms in on the heady, spiritual undercurrent of her past work for the new age Eternal Recurrence, which is hushed, meditative, and bathed in amber glow.

title: The Kid
label: Western Vinyl
description: On her most accessible album yet, Kaitlyn Aurelia Smith draws out the organic qualities of her Buchla 100 modular synth. But The Kid sparks a bodily pleasure alongside her music’s cerebral delights.

title: Trip
label: Def Jam
description: Written during a period of grief, Jhené Aiko’s 22-track LP turns her methods of survival—enlightenment, drugs, music itself—into an epic concept album. Some of Aiko’s most honest writing occurs here.

title: The Bigger Artist
label: Atlantic
description: The New York rapper’s promising debut showcases a 21-year-old who’s still finding his own lane between sensitivity and swagger.

title: Multi-task
label: Trouble in Mind
description: The wiry Atlanta, Ga. rock trio Omni sells its nervous energy as a logical way of dealing with the world. Where other bands might smooth things out, Omni finds angles and sharp turns.

title: As You Were
label: Warner Bros.
description: The debut solo album from the 45-year-old, would-be rock’n’roll savior fails to match the charm of his cantankerous public persona.

title: Neō Wax Bloom
label: Brainfeeder
description: The new album from Irish producer Iglooghost presents an alien landscape with only rare bits of human comfort. Even at its most elegant, it unfurls like a sensory attack.

title: Tell Me You Love Me
label: Island
description: On her sixth album, Demi Lovato finds a consistently compelling space: flinty, flirty R&B that’s just as thrilling hushed as it is at full blast.

title: Ash
label: XL
description: On their second album, the French-Cuban twins Lisa-Kaindé and Naomi Díaz make gorgeous, genre-agnostic meditations on resilience and mindful resistance.

title: Dream Theory in Malaya: Fourth World Volume Two
label: Glitterbeat
description: Trumpeter and composer Jon Hassell follows his own dream logic on this 1981 LP, which synthesized his hybrid of jazz and minimalism, ambient and exotica, ancient ethnic music and glitchy electronics.

title: Decreation
label: 20 Buck Spin
description: Under the influence of French philosopher Simone Weil, the Oakland quartet Acephalix offer the immediate hook of classic death metal on their third full-length.

title: Hiss Spun
label: Sargent House
description: Chelsea Wolfe dives headfirst into sludge metal and creates a unique space where sweetness can be heavy and contact is always uncomfortable.

title: New Energy
label: Text
description: Kieran Hebden’s pursuit of new sounds has found him digging into his own catalog. New Energy is a wide-ranging album that connects the warmth of his early work to his latest club experiments.

title: Dark Bliss
label: White Material
description: The debut album from the Cleveland-raised, New York-based producer is a dreamy, hypnotic style of hip-house. It’s a low-key album that keeps its pleasures close to its chest.

title: Relatives in Descent
label: Domino
description: The fourth album from the literary Detroit rock band Protomartyr is sinuous and allusive, dense and at times dizzying. It contains a constant sense of unease about the world and its future.

title: Visions of a Life
label: RCA
description: Wolf Alice proudly carry the banner for Britrock on their second album, a holy site where dead metaphors and teen clichés can spring magically back to life.

title: Always Foreign
artist: The World Is a Beautiful Place & I Am No Longer Afraid to Die
label: Epitaph
description: On their vital, bristling third LP, the band is at their most concise and vitriolic. Their songwriting suggests the world is an increasingly terrible place and we should all be scared to death.

title: Tommy EP
label: Hyperdub
description: On her exhilarating Hyperdub debut, the London electronic musician slathers on processed vocals in thick, inky layers, breaking feverishly free of the rhythmic grid.

title: If Blue Could Be Happiness
label: Double Double Whammy
description: The second full-length from New York folk-pop trio Florist distills their sound to its essence. It finds beauty in simplicity and strength in fragility, full of songs that are quietly commanding.

title: He’s the DJ, I’m the Rapper
artist: DJ Jazzy Jeff & The Fresh Prince
label: Jive
description: The duo’s 1988 goofy but undeniably catchy double-album mixed hip-hop bona fides with an effervescent MC. It would win over Middle America and score the first-ever Grammy for a rap album.

title: DJ-Kicks
label: !K7
description: Tapping Detroit techno, IDM, and boom-bap hip-hop, Lone’s horizontally inclined DJ-Kicks mix uses expert selection and programming to highlight his own distinctive musical sensibility.

title: Vilseledd
label: Party Smasher Inc.
description: Sweden’s God Mother blend black metal, d-beat, grind, math rock, and more, contorting tradition rather than kowtowing to it. Their hellish new album offers occasional glimpses of greatness.

title: VTM
label: VTM
description: The offbeat Chicago rapper’s knowing, laconic vocal style fits into the spare beats on his latest mixtape. It is deceptively cool and unpredictable.

title: Now
label: Mercury Nashville
description: Shania Twain’s fifth studio album and first in 15 years feels courageous. Her songs are modern and pleasant but the specter of her life’s temporary collapse hangs over its best tracks.

title: Younger Now
label: RCA
description: Bland production and weak songwriting hamstring the personalized nature of Younger Now, making it merely a suggestion of the kind of artist Miley Cyrus could be.

title: Paradise
label: self-released
description: After producing for Joey Purp and Vic Mensa and singing on Chance the Rapper’s “All Night,” Chicago’s Kevin Rhomberg steps up with his breezy debut album. It crystallizes his peculiar pop appeal.

title: La Confusion
label: Because Music
description: The long-married Malian duo confronts the country’s upheavals with an album of shimmering Afro-pop that urges hope and offers uplift.

title: The Centre Cannot Hold
label: Mute
description: Recording in Chicago with Steve Albini at the controls, Ben Frost unleashes volleys of brutalizing electronic sound as an allegory for the grim state of the world.

title: Harmony of Difference EP
label: Young Turks
description: Even on this shorter EP, saxophonist and composer Kamasi Washington displays a tireless ambition with his compositions, performance, and spiritual approach.

title: By Any Means 2
label: Bread Winners’ Association
description: The Baton Rouge rapper is still a fearsome MC in his prime. His latest mixtape cuts the distance between his singsongy, hook-driven punches and his cold, levelheaded lessons.

title: Experimental Music
label: Radical Elite
description: The sixth album from Ian Svenonius’ rock group Chain and the Gang could be his sharpest set of ironic arguments yet. Svenonius’ hot-wired backing band whips his clever tunes into tornados.

title: L’Rain
label: Astro Nautico
description: Brooklyn experimentalist Taja Cheek adopted the stage name L’Rain in 2014, and her debut is a beautiful, untidy conduit of her grieving. The album’s unconventional structures lend it a pastoral feel.

title: V
label: Caroline
description: On their fifth album, the Horrors retool their formula for retro-leaning, riff-laden arena rock in an attempt to reconnect with the “unsettling” spirit of their garage-rock roots.

title: Plum
label: Drag City
description: The new album from Cory Hanson’s band Wand is its most focused, finessed, and best record to date. It contains an audacious refinement that transcends the group’s beginnings in the garage-rock scene.

title: Roll With the Punches
label: Exile
description: Van Morrison’s 37th album is a thorough exploration of the blues. It’s crisp, precise, and reveals his ability to inhabit classic songs while paying respect to their form.

title: Aromanticism
label: Jagjaguwar
description: The debut album from Moses Sumney is a soulful, cosmic embrace of aloneness. His deep blue songwriting examines the blasé cruelty that defines intimacy in our swipe-left era.

title: Sun Gong / Bring on the Sun
label: All Saints
description: On his latest set of releases, the new age composer Laraaji delivers divine works full of drifting ambience. He offers sage advice and highlights the transformative power of ancient gong tones.

title: Young Martha EP
label: YSL
description: The first collaborative EP from Young Thug and the producer Carnage is an intriguing proposition, and it’s dazzling at times. But it seems to scratch the surface of their potential chemistry.

title: Gemini
label: Bendo
description: The new album from Macklemore—his first without collaborator Ryan Lewis since 2006—is a light listen with a couple of good moments and some innocuous clunkers, plus features from Lil Yachty and Offset.

title: Thrice Woven
label: Artemisia
description: On the follow-up to 2014’s electronic departure, Celestite, the Olympia band stumble in the attempt to find their way back to classic black metal.

title: Cold Dark Place EP
label: Reprise
description: The new Mastodon EP is an eclectic, psychedelic journey that sees guitarist/vocalist Brent Hinds picking up a Sho-Bud 13-string pedal steel guitar. His mastery of the instrument is quickly clear.

title: Living Water
label: Woodsist
description: L.A. singer-songwriter Shannon Lay’s new album is a work of plainspoken mysticism that goes to the small, bright truth of things, showcasing her unusual songwriting and quietly commanding voice.

title: The Spirit of Memphis (1962-1976)
label: Stax
description: Covering his prime years as Stax Records’ ace in the hole, this four-disc set presents Hayes as a complex, compelling bandleader, producer, and songwriter who reshaped the dimensions of soul.

title: Dulce Compañia
label: Incienso
description: On his full-length debut, the versatile Queens producer Brian Piñeyro adopts his serpentine alias to make the most of the dembow riddim’s slippery extremes.

title: Fabriclive 94
label: Fabric
description: The debut commercial mix CD from UK producer Harry Agius, aka Midland, transcends the typical function of a DJ mix. It’s one of the year’s best, with potential to resonate beyond dance-music diehards.

title: Elastica
label: Deceptive
description: With its pithy, searing songs about sex, groupies, and ennui, the self-titled 1995 debut from Elastica captured the whirlwind of the early-’90s Britpop explosion.

title: Stranger in the Alps
label: Dead Oceans
description: L.A. singer-songwriter Phoebe Bridgers’ debut LP is a collection of songs about intimacy, documenting how our relationships affect the way we view ourselves and interact with others.

title: Experiencing the Deposit of Faith
label: self-released
description: This self-released compilation from Yves Tumor is more atmospheric than last year’s excellent Serpent Music. Its 12 sketches account for some of the prettiest songs Tumor has made.

title: Their Satanic Majesties Request
label: ABKCO
description: Reissued for its 50th anniversary, Satanic Majesties remains a singular entry in the Stones’ catalog. It is the strange result of a bizarre set of personal, professional, and cultural circumstances.

title: Strange Peace
label: Sub Pop
description: The Toronto-based trio Metz have incorporated harmony into their heavy sound on their third full-length. They shift away from all-out abrasion, adding color to their eruptions.

title: I’m a Harmony
label: Omnivore
description: Like her 2014 comeback record, the new album from psych-folk artist Linda Perhacs features collaborations with Julia Holter and electronic touches, expanding the borders of her sound.

label: Light in the Attic
description: A new anthology of the oft-overlooked 1990s indie rockers zeroes in on what they did best: gentle jangle, tumbleweed drift, and hazy harmonies that display profound comfort in quietude.

title: Music for the Age of Miracles
label: Merge
description: On the first full album in seven years from the softly psychedelic British band, they’ve left something behind in the quest to recapture the essence of the Clientele.

title: Wonderful Wonderful
label: Island
description: With the Killers, greatness and ridiculousness go hand in hand. Their fifth album contains only a little of both.

title: You.Know.I.Got.It (The Album)
label: YOU.KNOW.I.GOT.IT Entertainment
description: Recorded over two years, the up-and-coming Berkeley rapper’s debut is intensely passionate and artfully subtle. Few rappers can say so much with so little.

title: Hallelujah Anyhow
label: Merge
description: Hiss Golden Messenger’s bittersweet, new LP is full of fluttery soul-grooves, borrowing from various regional folk and blues traditions. It speaks to what it means to be a compassionate citizen today.

title: Brand New Abyss
label: self-released
description: The duo of Khaela Maricich and Melissa Dyne venture into modular synthesis for the latest the Blow album. The change is not entirely positive, but it glimmers with some promising moments.

title: Luciferian Towers
label: Constellation
description: The sound of Godspeed’s radical fury takes a sideline on their impeccably composed sixth album. It contains their most melodic and powerfully positive-sounding music to date.

title: Haiku From Zero
label: Astralwerks
description: The Australian band’s reverence for reference is part of their allure and their fifth album sticks to the tried-and-true pop formulas of the past.

title: ununiform
label: !K7
description: On his 13th studio album, Tricky translates newfound contentment into songs that fail to live up to the risk-taking example of his early work.

title: Electric Trim
label: Mute
description: Lee Ranaldo’s latest album is his finest post-Sonic Youth solo effort, featuring collaborations with Sharon Van Etten, Nels Cline, Kid Millions, and lyrics co-written with novelist Jonathan Lethem.

title: Light Information
label: Sub Pop
description: The sixth proper album from Calgary-based multimedia auteur Chad VanGaalen is one of his finer efforts, demonstrating his uncanny knack for off-kilter songcraft.

title: Brick Body Kids Still Daydream
label: Mello Music Group
description: Armed with a caustic wit and a poetic eye, Open Mike Eagle builds a small, quiet monument to a housing project in Chicago across a diverse and singular piece of contemporary hip-hop.

title: Mourn
label: Wedidit
description: Teen R&B oddball Corbin Smidzik (fka Spooky Black) has refocused his energy. Working with Weeknd collaborator Doc McKinney, he hones his vocal talent, even going for some black metal-inspired screams.

title: Son of a Lady EP
label: Tendril Tales
description: The former Mazzy Star frontwoman presents three gentle tracks where her mature, reserved delivery gets tangled in threads of childlike whimsy.

title: Prophets of Rage
label: Concord Music Group
description: The power once held by Rage Against the Machine, Public Enemy, and Cypress Hill is spread far too thin and feels far too dated to sustain the momentum of the supergroup’s debut LP.

title: Concrete and Gold
label: Roswell
description: Nine albums in and Dave Grohl knows how to keep the machine running. Concrete and Gold is reliable, relatable, and powerful with just barely enough new ideas to keep things interesting.

title: Buy Muy Drugs
label: Ether Jung
description: The collaborative concept album from rapper Denmark Vessey and producer Azarias mixes Afro-Brazilian rhythms, grime, and bass to imagine a dystopian world in which desperation is the new normal.

title: Parallels
label: Innovative Leisure
description: The new album from L.A. producer Jason Chung, aka Nosaj Thing, is more open-ended than usual, bringing collaborators like Zuri Marley, Blonde Redhead’s Kazu Makino, and Steve Spacek into the fray.

title: Existence Problem EP
label: Pelican Fly
description: The 21-year-old Norwegian producer’s debut EP is driven by whimsy and promises a fresh spin on the Pelican Fly sound.

title: White Pony
label: Maverick
description: While living on houseboats in Sausalito, California, Deftones broke away from nu-metal and recorded the melodic highlight of their career, a moody album born of sex, Sade, and cocaine.

title: Event Horizon
label: Be With
description: Power pop band the Necessaries are best remembered for counting Arthur Russell and Modern Lovers’ Ernie Brooks as members. But there’s more to the story, as their newly reissued 1982 LP shows.

title: Half-Light
label: Nonesuch
description: The intimate, elliptical solo debut from producer and former Vampire Weekender gorgeously traces the stories and sounds of his past.

title: Discussions
label: Wide Hive
description: Five decades since co-founding the Art Ensemble of Chicago, the pioneering saxophonist offers innovative fusions of composition and improvisation on a rare album for large ensemble.

title: The Aviary
label: Atlantic
description: Swedish pop duo Galantis are gleeful vocal manipulators who have written for the likes of Britney Spears and Icona Pop. On their new LP, their maximalism takes on the halting sounds of tropical house.

title: Akira (Symphonic Suite)
label: Milan
description: The new vinyl reissue from Milan Records highlights the “sonic architecture” of Dr. Shoji Yamashiro’s intense and immersive suite of music.

title: Souvenirs
label: Plume
description: On her third LP, Seattle’s Shenandoah Davis turns breakups into pitch-perfect chamber pop, propelled by wise lyrics and her striking, classically-trained voice.

title: Wide Open
label: BMG
description: The erstwhile Doobie Brothers leader and Steely Dan associate’s first album in 20 years is more of an urbane R&B labor of love than an attempt to capitalize on his resurgent popularity.

title: Blue Velvet (Original Motion Picture Soundtrack)
label: Fire
description: The iconic soundtrack marks the beginning of Angelo Badalamenti’s 30-plus-year creative partnership with David Lynch; torn between terror and ecstasy, it is as full of mystery as his films.

title: Dedicated to Bobby Jameson
label: Mexican Summer
description: Refining the gonzo pop-collages of his previous work, Ariel Pink crafts an immersive, intimate record, marked by solitude.

title: Communicating
label: OWSLA
description: Carving out an intensely introspective space in the overlap between electronic and acoustic sounds, the Los Angeles trio’s third album traffics in melancholy and occasionally ecstatic moods.

title: Ardor
label: Southern Lord
description: Channeling squalls of feedback and waves of downtuned guitars, Montreal’s BIG|BRAVE represent the raw unconscious turned up as loud as their amps will go.

title: Deer Tick Vol. 1 / Deer Tick Vol. 2
label: Partisan
description: On their latest release, which is two whole albums long, Deer Tick offer an acoustic set and an electric one. The discs both contain a more settled outlook from bandleader John McCauley than usual.

title: Running Back Mastermix
label: Running Back
description: The New York DJ Tony Humphries mixes an impeccably smooth course through disco-inflected house from Germany’s Running Back label.

title: The Gradual Progression
label: Rvng Intl.
description: Greg Fox’s second solo album is spiritually ecstatic. The once and future metal drummer finds new clarity in electronic, ambient, and even New Age sounds.

title: Native Invader
label: Decca
description: The 15th album from one of pop’s most inventive composers as a braid of political, maternal, and celestial statements. Amos’ intricately arranged songs are passionate and despairingly poetic.

title: CCCLX
label: LuckyMe
description: The debut LP from Montreal producer Lunice (one-half of TNGHT) is intended as the score for a speculative theater piece, but the music alone comes off garish and retrograde.

title: Hippopotamus
label: BMG
description: On the first proper Sparks album in nearly a decade, the Mael brothers let existential anxiety into their bouncy music more overtly than usual.

title: A Moment Apart
label: Counter
description: The electronic duo Odesza are at the center of the current movement in stadium-filling ”chill” music. Their latest is full of billowing vocal harmonies, seismic rumble, and turbo-charged trap beats.

title: 1992 Deluxe
label: Rough Trade
description: On her newly reissued and expanded 2016 mixtape, Destiny Frasqueri—aka Princess Nokia—raps with granular detail about mysticism, childhood, and her native New York City.

title: In Search of Lost Time
label: You've Changed
description: Defiantly queer, proudly Canadian, and righteously stoned, Ontario’s Partner infuse their bubble-grunge indie-rock riffs with a slyly subversive spirit.

title: Hitchhiker
label: Reprise
description: Recorded over one night in 1976, Hitchhiker is an acoustic snapshot of Neil Young’s creative process, captured at a time when he was crafting music strong enough to last his whole career.

title: MAKANDA at the End of Space, the Beginning of Time
label: Bonsound
description: Uniting musicians from Kinshasa, Montreal, and Seattle, Pierre Kwenders’ second album, produced by Shabazz Palaces’ Tendai Maraire, is a wildly inventive, globe-spanning triumph.

title: The Hanged Man
label: self-released
description: On his first album in seven years, Ted Leo faces down private and public upheaval, as personal tragedy and political calamity fuel the most expansive, emotionally devastating music of his career.

title: Love What Survives
label: Warp
description: Mount Kimbie harness their command of detail—plus star turns from King Krule and James Blake—on a rhythm-driven album that feels less like electronic music and more like the work of a full band.

title: Thx
label: Double Double Whammy
description: The second album from Texas songwriter Hannah Read—the creative force at the heart of Lomelda—is alternately quiet and erupting, with immediately arresting melodies that long for closeness and wonder.

title: Outrage! Is Now
label: Warner Bros.
description: The Toronto dance-punk duo’s new album sees them embracing maturity, bringing in more reflection, more funk, more production finesse, and—crucially—more hooks.

title: Red
label: Island
description: Red stands as one of classic rock’s heaviest albums and also one of its most meticulous. With its dark, meditative sheen, it laid the groundwork for Robert Fripp’s more atmospheric work to come.

title: Forced Witness
label: Secretly Canadian
description: The art-sleaze of Alex Cameron’s second album transcends its surface-level smarm to become a biting piece of commentary. Thankfully, the songs are as effortlessly catchy as they are eminently creepy.

title: Out of All This Blue
label: BMG
description: Mike Scott takes his long-running Irish/Scottish folk rock band the Waterboys into new terrain on his latest LP—incorporating four-four disco stomp, a heavy dose of hip-hop, and romantic love.

title: How Did I Find Myself Here?
label: Anti-
description: On their first album in nearly 30 years, the Paisley Underground group reintroduce some of what made their 1982 debut—atmospheric rock music veering between noise and subtlety—so compelling.

title: Mountain Moves
label: Joyful Noise
description: Mountain Moves is one of Deerhoof’s widest-ranging and most melodic sets, with hints of chamber music, hip-hop, and avant-garde jazz, plus more legible lyrics than usual. It’s a purposeful mosaic.

title: Fifth Harmony
label: Epic
description: Now down to a quartet, the group’s latest album falls short of the kind of stellar pop songwriting they once possessed.

title: Sleep Well Beast
label: 4AD
description: The band’s seventh album adds more chaos to their stately drama. It is full of abandon and quiet contemplation, as Matt Berninger sings not about how to enjoy life, but how to simply endure it.

title: I Can’t Stand It Here on Quiet Nights: Singles 1981-82
label: Silent Street
description: Like many of their early ’80s UK peers, Maximum Joy mixed punk, funk, disco, and reggae. This new set captures a band carving its own place with two of music’s most powerful tools: muscle and joy.

title: Ariadna
label: 2MR
description: Working with classic hardware synths, the Russian musician makes dark, dreamlike techno infused with her ethereal vocals.

title: Antisocialites
label: Polyvinyl
description: The second album from the Toronto indie pop band is nothing but thoroughly accomplished songs. Alvvays have sharpened their focus without losing sight of themselves.

title: Death Valley Oasis
label: Anticon
description: The producer and guitarist D33J has long been an integral behind-the-scenes member of L.A. beat collective WEDIDIT. His immersive debut full-length contains the surreal lushness its title suggests.

title: The Echo of Pleasure
artist: The Pains of Being Pure at Heart
label: Painbow
description: Full of gleaming exteriors, the latest album from the Pains of Being Pure at Heart is essentially a solo outing from frontman Kip Berman, who was on the brink of fatherhood when he wrote it.

title: Okovi
label: Sacred Bones
description: Okovi showcases the searing, fully-formed music of Nika Danilova, an album of close personal experiences rendered into urgent goth-pop songs as emotional as they are necessary.

title: Saturation II
label: EMPIRE
description: On their second album in as many months, the Los Angeles rap crew stay sleek and cool, but offer more appealing bouts of aggression and swagger.

title: Poor David’s Almanack
label: Acony
description: David Rawlings finds news ways of inhabiting old folk music alongside his longtime musical partner Gillian Welch. There’s a crisp intimacy to his new solo effort, but also a self-awareness.

title: The Source
label: Blue Note
description: On this hybrid album of jazz and Afrobeat, long-time Fela Kuti drummer Tony Allen makes the complex sound effortless. Rarely has percussive innovation sounded this downright satisfying.

title: Twin Peaks (Music From the Limited Event Series)
label: Rhino
description: The hallucinatory performances at the Roadhouse in Twin Peaks: The Return are collected on a new soundtrack, celebrating a triumph of musical programming, mood, and David Lynch’s strange reality.

title: Omnion
label: Atlantic
description: Andy Butler’s fourth album as Hercules and Love Affair delivers the subtle genre pivot that was so needed to reinvigorate their standing as the elder gatekeepers of club music history.

title: Superchunk
label: Merge
description: It’s a blast to remember how versatile Superchunk are on their newly-reissued 1990 debut. It features all the embryonic styles of their power-pop-punk at once, with awkward, utterly alive exuberance.

title: Every Country’s Sun
label: Temporary Residence
description: With David Fridmann producing, the latest Mogwai album contains the same bratty conviction that defined their greatest records, like there’s something truly at stake.

title: Popeye: Original Motion Picture Soundtrack
label: Varese Saraband
description: Newly reissued to include the storied demo sessions, Harry Nilsson’s soundtrack to Robert Altman’s 1980 film is a mind-meld of two artists, a mournful little under-appreciated classic.

title: Country Grammar
label: Universal Records
description: Nelly’s 2000 debut brought the life and sound of St. Louis to the world. It’s a syntactical maze of local culture that doubles as a flier for the greatest party you could ever imagine.

title: Urban Hymns
label: Virgin
description: The Verve’s blockbuster third album—newly reissued in a five-disc expanded edition—has come to be seen as the swan song for Britpop’s cultural hegemony. But in 1997, it felt like a step forward.

title: Toy
label: Merge
description: The fourth album from Austin, Tx.’s A Giant Dog fuses the gaudy delivery of 1970s rock and the pillars of modern punk. Its songs offer lyrics about sex without typical depictions of love.

title: The Pacific Visions of Martin Glass
label: Kit
description: The electronic artist Martin Glass makes lounge music informed by exotica, emulating 1970s nippon pop, neo-classical, and ambient. Most of the sounds here are charming and innocuous.

title: Dixieland
label: Flesh and Bone
description: Playing remarkably tuneful pop-rock at sludgy tempos, the Flint, Mich. trio Greet Death benefit from isolation. Their debut album is full of bludgeoning tones and diamond-cut production.

title: we think we alone EP
label: self-released
description: On his new EP, the 21-year-old Queens singer presents a series of heart-rending song sketches inspired by loss.

title: American Dream
label: Columbia
description: The rebirth of LCD Soundsystem is marked by an extraordinary album obsessed with endings: of friendships, of love, of heroes, of a certain type of geeky fandom, and of the American dream itself.

title: Trash Generator
label: Sargent House
description: On Trash Generator, the Sacramento trio Tera Melos builds on its prodigious mix of post-hardcore and prog, reining-in the chops in service of catchy, harmonically rich songs.

title: Holiday Destination
description: The third album from the UK singer-songwriter is unerringly compassionate. Her brooding post-punk is an unsettling backdrop for songs about the refugee crisis, Islamophobia, and poisonous politicians.

title: Cozy Tapes Vol. 2: Too Cozy
label: RCA
description: A$AP Mob’s latest group effort features RZA, Frank Ocean, Chief Keef, Quavo and more, but the Mob’s energy and skill are consistently eclipsed by that of their guests.

title: Results
label: SFE
description: The newly reissued 1989 collaboration between Liza Minelli and the Pet Shop Boys is a fascinating, addled mix of show tunes, strings, and 808s that coalesces in a mood of chic Upper East Side regret.

title: Sketches of Brunswick East
label: Flightless
description: On their third full-length of 2017 alone, the Melbourne psych-rock band are surprisingly agile, incorporating soul, jazz, North African overtones, and pastoral English folk.

label: EMPIRE
description: The Florida rapper’s debut album is muted and mired with pain, trauma, and controversy. The reasons it is difficult to listen to can overshadow the need to listen to it.

title: No Mountains in Manhattan
label: XL
description: Wiki’s new album is an acidic and vivid manifestation of his city, at times surreal and too real, with contributions from Earl Sweatshirt, Kaytranada, Ghostface Killah, and more.

title: Bicep
label: Ninja Tune
description: On their debut album, the Irish duo Bicep—founders of the blog-turned-party and label Feel My Bicep—offer a lean and consciously paced survey of UK dance sounds with hints of psychedelia.

title: Rainbow Edition
label: Big Dada
description: The first LP from Hype Williams in six years is ostensibly helmed not by its founders—Dean Blunt & Inga Copeland—but by a duo called Slaughter & Silvermane. It’s full of sludgy 808s and cheap synths.

title: Luv Is Rage 2
label: Atlantic
description: Uzi’s latest project comes very close to delivering on the chaotic, sublime promise of “XO Tour Llif3.” It’s the Philly rapper’s  most musically developed work to date.

title: A Man Called Destruction
label: Omnivore
description: In the mid-1990s, Alex Chilton entered a Memphis studio to track a collection of deep R&B and pop covers. The results were fascinating and frustrating in equal measure.

title: Afrobeat Hot Hits: New Urban Dance Grooves From Africa
label: Shanachie
description: A new compilation of this hybrid Nigerian dance music—popularized in the U.S. by the likes of Drake and Diplo—shows that with Afrobeats, there’s much more than one dance.

title: Blue Chips 7000
label: Vice
description: Action Bronson’s second studio album is also the third installment of his Blue Chips mixtape series. It’s full of bare raps and funky beats, of unadorned samples and dopey swaggering.

title: Project Baby 2
label: Atlantic
description: On the Florida rapper’s latest project, he’s less measured than he’s been in the past. The moments of transparency are overshadowed by disingenuous storytelling and colorless punch lines.

title: TFCF
label: Mute
description: Now working solo, Liars’ Angus Andrew looks back on the dissolution of his group with a strange, often contradictory album conceived in self-imposed isolation.

title: Villains
label: Matador
description: With production flourishes from Mark Ronson, Josh Homme leads the band's most accessible album in decades. It’s equal parts disco inferno and devil-may-care experimentation.

title: Beaucoup Fish
label: UMC
description: Originally released in 1999, Underworld's newly reissued rave-inspired fifth LP is often thrilling, but is mainly a fascinating snapshot of the UK group at a moment of ambivalence.

title: Paranoia
label: Def Jam
description: The Harlem rapper’s latest project merges mainstream and underground rap flows while combating the perils of newfound success.

title: Gypsy Woman
label: Fania
description: Singer, songwriter, pianist, and bandleader Joe Bataan took boogaloo to its peak with Gypsy Woman, combining soul, mambo, and traditional Latin tunes and became a mainstay for the famous Fania label.

title: Brown Sugar
label: Virgin
description: D’Angelo’s debut was a sudden shock to ’90s R&B. The deluxe, expanded version of Brown Sugar reveals the extent to which it was grown folks music made by a 21-year-old genius.

title: Freudian
label: Golden Child
description: On his debut album, Toronto R&B singer Daniel Caesar looks to gospel for a roadmap to the complexities of romantic love.

title: Electro-Soma I + II
label: Warp
description: In the early ’90s, B12 were the best example of Detroit’s influence on IDM, and the reissue of Electro-Soma alongside a new compilation is a fearsomely beautiful work of electronic head music.

title: Invitation
label: Kill Rock Stars
description: Sleater-Kinney’s Corin Tucker and R.E.M. guitarist Peter Buck team up for a crisp, allusive record that taps into their gnarled indie rock and punk roots.

title: Good Nature
label: Run for Cover
description: The last album from Virginia-born band Turnover found a sweet spot between pop-punk and dream pop, but their influences are more sedate and smooth this time.

title: Aytche
label: Western Vinyl
description: The debut album from saxophonist Joseph Shabason, best known for his work with Destroyer, shows a new side of his instrument. He uses electronics to create a kind of ambient jazz.

title: Exile in the Outer Ring
label: City Slang
description: Erika M. Anderson’s third solo album is a surreal and powerful story about political alienation. Her character-driven songs of noise, folk, and pop music thrum with rage and fear.

title: A Deeper Understanding
label: Atlantic
description: The obsessive studio work of Adam Granduciel creates a hermetic experience like no other. A Deeper Understanding is his most layered and meticulous album, a twilight world in which to lose yourself.

title: So Numb
label: Profound Lore
description: Brooklyn trio Sannhet is an instrumental powerhouse. On So Numb, they shake loose of their black metal and post-rock roots, making heavy music with their own beautiful language.

title: Black Ken
label: BasedWorld
description: Years of online myth-making have culminated with Lil B’s masterpiece Black Ken, 27 tracks of deep funk and hyphy that finally defines the mercurial Based God.

title: Far From Over
label: ECM
description: Following last year’s duo album with trumpeter Wadada Leo Smith, pianist Vijay Iyer debuts a powerhouse sextet lineup to tackle some of his strongest, most varied writing yet.

title: Beast Epic
label: Sub Pop
description: Sam Beam brings Iron & Wine full circle on his sixth album, using the warm acoustic instrumentation of his early work and some of the most moving singing of his career.

title: Science Fiction
label: Procrastinate! Music Traitors
description: Brand New’s fifth album stands as a monument to their gradual evolution. It is a wise and vulnerable conclusion for a rock band who were crucial in shaping a scene, a sound, and many emotions.

title: S/T
label: Polyvinyl
description: The new LP from revived emo band Rainer Maria presents a slower, heavier, and more methodical version of the group. It’s a reunion album that stacks up well against their most cherished work.

title: Orc
label: Castle Face
description: With their latest full-length, and a minor name change, John Dwyer’s garage-punk band continues to travel further toward rock’s outer limits.

title: Take Flight
label: I/AM/ME
description: The first major release in three years from British DJ and producer Maya Jane Coles—once sampled by Nicki Minaj—is a moody two-hour collection that highlights her weaknesses.

title: The Water We Drink
label: Posh Isolation
description: The Danish trio’s daring album takes a fluid approach to arrangement and song structure, balancing their industrial, noisier tendencies by engaging with the broader realm of pop music.

title: Tropical Drums of Deutschland
label: Music For Dreams
description: The Salon des Amateurs resident DJ combs his collection of exotica to produce a compilation of globe-trotting ambient and drum-driven dancefloor cuts.

title: Alice Glass EP
label: Loma Vista
description: On her first solo EP since leaving Crystal Castles, Alice Glass clears more room for her voice and words, softening the jagged edges that had characterized her previous work.

title: Ripe & Majestic
label: Rad Cult
description: For his latest Tobacco collection, Tom Fec of Black Moth Super Rainbow compiles 24 tracks spanning 2007 to present. They testify to his proficiency as an arranger of queasy electronic psychedelia.

title: Terra Incognita
label: Emotional Rescue
description: Drawing from two long-out-of-print compilations from the mid 1980s, this abridged reissue documents experiments in fusion—mixing post-punk, electronic, and fourth world—that sound both as strange and as relevant as ever.

title: 1 Up Top Ahk
label: Mozzy
description: The prolific Sacramento rapper’s latest has that bass and funk-heavy production but is deeply haunted by death. It unfolds like the diary of a man haunted by a past he’s trying to outrun.

title: Still Striving
label: RCA
description: Though he’s still got style on the mic, Ferg’s latest is a regression into the gleeful ignorance that colored his earlier work.

title: Time Well
label: Relapse
description: Though longer and mellower, Cloakroom’s second album still has an anxious, open-ended feel. They take the appealing parts of a masculine pose without being wholly trapped by them.

title: Songs From the Big Chair
label: Mercury
description: Tears for Fears’ second album is the one sound of pop-rock in the ’80s. Its personal psychology, meticulous compositions, and world-sized choruses evoked the loss of control in an overwhelming era.

title: Link Wray
label: Future Days
description: In 1971, Link Wray reinvented himself and made one of the greatest roots rock albums ever, full of fuzz blasts, gnarled folk, and backwoods gospel. Rock’n’roll doesn’t get leaner or more primal.

title: Warmth
label: R & S
description: On their first album in four years, Brooklyn’s Blondes hone in on more overt dancefloor energies while maintaining the dreamy introspection that is their signature.

title: Policies of Power EP
label: Lucky Number
description: Samantha Urbani’s debut is alt-pop with style and nuance. She coats her sound with some retro ’80s accessories, but her real emotions remain grounded in the present.

title: Althaea
label: Double Six
description: The London duo incorporate more varied and esoteric sounds to create an album of fun but flawed 1980s-inspired sophisti-pop.

title: A Fever Dream
label: RCA
description: The Manchester band are attuned to the absurdity of our times. The hyperactive synthpop of their fourth LP is full of surreal vignettes evoking our increasingly nightmarish world.

title: Living EP
label: No World
description: While fitting comfortably into their discography of slinky slow jams, Living finds the Los Angeles R&B duo unsure of how to connect to the vital essence of the genre.

title: Across the Multiverse
label: Carpark
description: Like a crooner in outer space, Dent May makes glum sounds that sound happy, with old-fashioned panache. But the production of his latest collection is dense and muddled.

title: Painted Ruins
label: RCA
description: The intricate compositions on the band’s fifth album are bound tighter than ever, evoking distant images and emotions that continually shift in and out of focus.

title: b.
label: Fool's Gold
description: Brittany Bosco’s latest project elevates smooth R&B and Afrofuturism from off the streets of Atlanta with an emotional, bop-heavy set of songs.

title: Come Over When You’re Sober (Part One)
label: self-released
description: On his debut album, the alternately waggish and sincere Lil Peep is bona fide rocker warping the edges of rap.

title: Candy-O / Panorama
label: Rhino
description: Expanded reissues of the Cars’ second and third albums capture the group running like a well-oiled machine, both refining and expanding upon their tightly wound new wave.

title: Pool Party
label: EYRST
description: The Portland party rapper’s debut album is darker and more introspective than his past work, with features from the Last Artful, Dodgr, Michael Christmas, and Blossom.

title: Like a Prayer
label: Sire
description: Madonna’s spectacular fourth album revealed just how grand, artistic, and personal a pop star could be at the very height of her fame.

title: Madonna
label: Warner Bros.
description: The driving force of Madonna’s debut remains its palpable physicality, born out of New York dance clubs, a new pop mandate to move your body in ways both public and private.

title: Bedtime Stories
label: Maverick
description: Released in 1994, the warm and mellow sound of Madonna’s sixth album has its seductive charms, but of all her work, it remains a curious non-event in the pop star‘s wildly eventful career.

title: Ray of Light
label: Warner Bros.
description: Channeling acid electronica, Kabbalah, and motherhood, Madonna’s 1998 reinvention stripped away the controversy of her past and became one of her most unexpectedly successful albums.

title: AI YoungBoy
label: self-released
description: The teenage Baton Rouge rapper’s latest mixtape an intense and emotional collection about finding new power in freedom. His versatility and charisma are shaping a style that’s all his own.

title: Verisimilitude
label: Pi
description: If the jazz and experimental drummer’s work in other bands often suggests an irrepressible mania, the goal with this trio seems to be delicate chaos.

title: Safely Nobody’s
label: Exploding in Sound
description: As Tall Friend, the singer-songwriter Charlie Pfaff makes bare-bones indie rock that processes trauma and recovery. Their modest debut cloaks its hurt in warmth.

title: Anthology Resource Vol. 1 △△
label: Sacred Bones
description: A collection of soundtrack cues from the third season of “Twin Peaks,” Anthology Resource Vol. 1 is most effective when it remains in the background, tugging at the edges of your subconscious.

title: Last Chance
label: Infinite Best
description: House of Feelings make euphoric New York house music packed with modern anxieties. Their promising debut EP is intricate and elegant, featuring guest vocals from Shamir, Meredith Graves, and GABI.

title: Bushwick (Original Motion Picture Soundtrack)
label: Lakeshore
description: Much like his rhymes, Aesop Rock’s score for the action thriller Bushwick is packed with captivating detail; it’s an excellent fit for the film’s unrelenting intensity.

title: Elastic
label: Winspear
description: The lo-fi bedroom pop that defined Indiana singer-songwriter Amy Oelsner’s early career grows much larger on her latest album. She uses new instrumentation to express old feelings of anger, longing, and fear.

title: Good Time (Original Motion Picture Soundtrack)
label: Warp
description: Daniel Lopatin accentuates the Safdie Brothers’ character studies with his hyper-real music. Instead of pursuing moments of trance-like calm or humor, here he metes out anxiety measure by measure.

title: Tidal
label: Sony
description: Rare is a debut so fully formed and overflowing with music and emotion. Tidal grapples eloquently with loneliness, retribution, and the oceanic ups and downs of being young and being a woman.

label: RCA
description: A$AP Twelvyy’s long-awaited solo debut wears its love for New York City proudly but is plagued with inconsistencies.

title: The Fickle Finger of Fate/A Walk With Love & Death
label: Joyful Noise
description: After over three decades of drumming in the Melvins, Dale Crover has released a muffled, scattershot solo album. It comes on the heels of a new record from the Melvins themselves.

title: Popular Manipulations
label: Fat Possum
description: On their third full-length, Pennsylvania rock band the Districts dives headfirst into the earnest indie rock of the mid-2000s, displaying a new emotional depth.

title: Boy in a Well
label: Bloodshot
description: With Tommy Stinson producing, Denver trio the Yawpers mix a high-brow literary streak with messy rock’n’roll on their third album. They cherrypick from punk, rockabilly, and the blues in the process.

title: Rainbow
label: RCA
description: Kesha’s musical career has been defined by her work with Dr. Luke. On her third album, she begins something new and promising.

title: How Do You Spell Heaven
label: GBV
description: On Guided by Voices’ latest, Robert Pollard sounds reenergized by a sobering sense of lucidity. Some of these songs rank among the most intimate and earthbound in the band’s bottomless canon.

title: Onism
label: Astro Nautico
description: Working within a fairly heavy philosophical framework, New York’s Photay has made some of his most captivating electronic music yet, with nimble house and disco rhythms and real emotional weight.

title: Bright Phoebus
label: Domino
description: Once considered too weird for the folk crowd and too pastoral for the rock crowd, this obscure 1972 masterpiece gets a long-overdue reissue—a testament to its creators’ faith, perseverance, and genius.

title: Shitty Hits
label: Ba Da Bing!
description: The second album from the Maryland singer-songwriter is sharp and beguiling, carried by Katie Von Schleicher’s innate and economic pop instincts.

title: who told you to think?​?​!​!​?​!​?​!​?​!
label: Ruby Yacht
description: milo is a sharp-tongued rapper whose wordplay rewards close listening. On his third and best LP, the Maine emcee carries the flag for the underground rap scene that birthed him.

title: Cage Tropical
label: Slumberland
description: With subtle tweaks to her sound, Frankie Rose shows that her glossy, new wave style can be a way of cutting through the murk to find clarity.

title: Tessellatum
label: Bedroom Community
description: Composed by Donnacha Dennehy and performed on viola by Nadia Sirota and viol de gamba by Liam Byrne, Tessellatum is an impressive, sweeping work whose 15 pieces seem to just peel off one another.

title: S’WOMEN
label: self-released
description: Stas offers a sharp solo debut doused heartbreak, identity, and the familiar production touches of her former futurist rap and R&B duo THEESatisfaction.

title: Cost of Living
label: Sub Pop
description: On their latest LP, produced by Fugazi’s Guy Picciotto, Downtown Boys present their thundering political punk with a richer sound. Singer Victoria Ruiz presses deep into the poetics of confrontation.

title: Yellow
label: Captured Tracks
description: Olympia punk trio Naomi Punk’s third album is a 75-minute, 25-track study in repetition. They’ve become more interested in deconstructing their songs than writing them.

title: Soul of a Nation — Afro-Centric Visions in the Age of Black Power: Underground Jazz, Street Funk, & the Roots of Rap 1968-79
label: Soul Jazz
description: Soul Jazz Records’ companion to the Tate Modern’s exhibition of black art from the 1960s traces pivotal developments in funk, soul, jazz, and spoken word that still resonate through popular music today.

title: Hamtramck ’16
label: Arbutus
description: Moon King’s Daniel Benjamin moves from shoegaze to disco on his latest release, but his version of the genre sounds too flat and tinny to survive on the dance floor.

title: Fried Shallots EP
label: Drag City
description: The brief odds and sods charity EP from Ty Segall brings both the eternal comfort of his garage rock and the joy of something new and mellow.

title: The Golden Mile EP
label: Tag Out
description: Inspired by Brooklyn’s current electronic scene and ’80s acid house, the New York trio applies a sophisticated sheen to analog-driven electro-pop.

title: Boy Who Cried Wolf
label: Alamo
description: The Palm Beach rapper shows turn-up promise on his latest, but much of this project feels like it’s coasting on autopilot.

title: 50,000,000 Elvis Fans Can’t Be Wrong
label: Western Vinyl
description: On this re-release of her 2014 cassette, the Austin-based songwriter Caroline Sallee offers homespun solo recordings that draw on C86, bossa nova, and soothing folk music.

title: A Black Mile to the Surface
label: Loma Vista
description: Manchester Orchestra’s new album is their most confounding and thrilling work yet, with the most grandiose narrative concepts, production, and arrangements of their career.

title: Refresher EP
label: Planet Mu
description: Moving away from the abstracted electronica of earlier releases, the Scottish producer embraces streamlined rhythms and a newfound sense of clarity.

title: Dark Matter
label: Nonesuch
description: Dark Matter is Randy Newman’s first album of new songs in nine years and his smart mix of cynicism and sentiment is fully intact.

title: Good Morning Spider
label: Parlophone
description: Mark Linkous’ second album as Sparklehorse shines an old light on impossible things. He found the purity of pop music and then lacerated it with the quirks and imperfections he cherished.

title: Late Night Tales
label: Night Time Stories Ltd.
description: With their entry in the long-running mix series Late Night Tales, the Canadian band BADBADNOTGOOD offer an eclectic, uncompromising, and delightful “soundtrack for reflection and meditation.”

title: Dead Cross
label: Ipecac
description: Though led by a fiery performance from Mike Patton, this Slayer/Retox/the Locust supergroup doesn’t shed much new light on the players involved.

title: Collection
label: Fat Possum
description: The songwriter Sophie Allison has built a following with her Bandcamp bedroom recordings, but on this new record, she upgrades to a full band, giving her mournful songs a little extra drive.

title: Sacred Horror in Design
label: Opal Tapes
description: The producer Sote makes mind-melting electronic music at the center of a vital scene in Tehran. On his latest record, he applies his customary digital processing to traditional Persian instruments.

title: Call It Love
label: Jagjaguwar
description: Briana Marela’s third album of effervescent synth pop is her punchiest effort yet, full of songs that portray the anxiety of falling in and out of love.

title: Nervous System EP
label: Republic
description: After penning hits for Selena Gomez and Hailee Steinfeld, Julia Michaels brings her chart-topping songwriter chops to her solo career. The songs are refreshingly unique but their impact is varied.

title: Content
label: Hollywood
description: The second album from the synth-pop group finds them getting anxious about their own ambition, a feeling that doesn't always gracefully adapt to the dance floor.

title: Threshold of Faith EP
label: Mute
description: Assisted by Steve Albini, the Australian-born, Iceland-based electronic musician summons a gargantuan, apocalyptic din—one that is occasionally tripped up by its own bombast.

title: Contempt
label: Gilead Media
description: On their second album, the abrasive New York band Couch Slut draw on hardcore, grindcore, and metal while offering unflinching lyrics about violence and terror.

title: Verse
label: Topshelf
description: The second LP from People Like You is a fusion of jazz musicianship, emo spirit, and indie-pop tunefulness. It’s a mix so coherent that even the ugly parts are beautiful in their precision.

title: Here Come the Warm Jets / Taking Tiger Mountain (By Strategy) / Before and After Science
label: Virgin EMI
description: Brian Eno’s run of rock albums in the ’70s was an unprecedented achievement in music built on aleatory synth settings, fiery guitar work, subconscious lyrics, and of course, Oblique Strategies.

title: Tchornobog
label: Fallen Empire
description: On the ambitious new album from Ukrainian metal prodigy Markov Soroka, songs boil in their own misery. His dismal riffs and atmospheres bubble over until there’s nothing left but smoke.

title: Perfect Timing
label: Boominati Worldwide
description: After signing to the Weeknd’s label XO, Toronto rapper-producer Navraj Goraya is releasing a full-length collaboration with Atlanta producer Metro Boomin. He sounds as lyrically hollow as ever.

title: fantasii
label: Halcyon Veil
description: Positioning their alter ego Mhysa as a queer black underground pop star for the cyber resistance, the multimedia artist E. Jane constructs an elaborate alternate universe out of experimental club rhythms.

title: Golden
label: Sony
description: The Bronx-born pop star expands his musical empire on Golden. But for the all the album’s myriad sounds, its roots are firmly planted in bachata, the sounds of the campo.

title: The Elements
label: Concord Music Group
description: Alice Coltrane teamed with Joe Henderson for this 1973 jazz classic, an album where each member’s playing is in service of a single, cosmic statement of music.

title: What Do You Think About the Car?
label: Columbia
description: The 18-year-old UK singer-songwriter Declan McKenna has been called a voice of his generation. His major label debut is scattershot, though it includes a Rostam-helmed standout.

title: Sounds from the Other Side
label: Starboy
description: Emerging as a pop star from Nigeria’s Afrobeats scene, WizKid’s stateside debut is a potent crossover album that blends pop, R&B, dancehall and features Drake, Trey Songz, Ty Dolla $ign and more.

title: La Torre Ibiza — Volumen Dos
label: Hostel La Torre
description: Two veteran selectors propose an ideal soundtrack for sunset on Ibiza, drawing from Japanese electro-pop, soundtrack classics, and recent productions with a Balearic mindset.

title: Good for You
label: CLBN
description: The Portland rapper’s debut album balances playful verses and cheerful wit with more revealing moments of introspection.

title: Ceilings
label: Styles Upon Styles
description: Stepping out from her futuristic soul duo with Sene, Denitia’s electro-pop Ceilings is her most fully formed solo effort so far.

title: Lack
label: Pan
description: Using voice and synthesizer, the Shanghai-born, Berlin-based artist channels operatic tropes and controlled explosions of noise into visceral and cathartic forms.

title: The Autobiography
label: Roc Nation
description: The Chicago rapper’s first milestone is a careful step in his legacy-building business. It's an obvious turn inward, but Vic also digs his heels into his political ground.

title: The Outsiders EP
label: Magicwire
description: With the crackling sounds of “lo-fi house” achieving autoplay ubiquity in the dance music corners of YouTube, one of the micro-genre’s progenitors runs up against the style’s limits.

title: American Water
label: Drag City
description: In 1998, David Berman approached perfection. Absorbed in metaphor, ennui, and isolation, the loping music of American Water didn’t seem like it was trying to be art. It just was.

title: Sudan Archives
label: Stones Throw
description: The Los Angeles-based singer and violinist blends avant-garde experimentalism with the swagger-drenched posturing of club rap, ’90s R&B grooves, and biting introspection.

title: Riding the Thin Line EP
label: Anotherday
description: A fundamental EP from the Detroit techno titan gets reissued 18 years after its release; aimed squarely at the dancefloor, its three cuts are by turns gooey, steely, and strange.

title: Patterns for Resonant Space
label: Youngbloods
description: This avant-garde trio use piano, samples, and carefully skewered tapes to conjure an evocative sense of place. They drift to exquisite effect.

title: New Facts Emerge
label: Cherry Red
description: Mark E. Smith’s meaty, swollen approach to garage rock may bristle fans of his early work, but the album’s little touches and turns makes this more than an average release for a legacy band.

title: Greenspan and Taraval EP
label: Geej
description: Jeremy Greenspan and Ryan Smith’s hardware experiment EP is fundamentally a dance album, but the intelligent tracks skew more subtle and heady than their solo work.

title: Everything Now
label: Columbia
description: The Montreal band’s fifth album finds them in musical and lyrical stasis. The pale, joyless songs don’t transcend their social critique, they succumb to it.

title: Rotations
label: Thrill Jockey
description: The Portland duo Golden Retriever have created their own musical language using bass clarinet and a modular synth rig. Rotations expands their sound, adding 10 classical musicians to the mix.

title: Hate Songs EP
label: LuckyMe
description: Stepping away from his habitual trap beats and claustrophobic atmospheres, the New Orleans producer goes in search of wide-open vistas and melancholy maximalism.

title: LoveJoys
label: Small Press
description: The second album from Seattle soul-rock quintet Pickwick finds the band with a renewed sense of harmony. But some songs make you wonder if it would have benefitted from more discord.

title: Habit EP
label: Sister Polygon
description: The newly reissued six-song EP from the Maryland indie-pop band wallows in uncertainty and transition—but their songwriting makes it feel both adolescent and eternal.

title: Strange Days
label: Numbers
description: This new release from Italian producer Lory D compiles and digitizes five recent EPs, previously only available on vinyl. It’s a behemoth document of organic, shapeshifting techno.

title: Wins and Losses
label: Maybach Music Group
description: After freeing himself from the feuds and narrative that dragged him down, Meek Mill’s third studio album is a comeback by any measure, honest and gripping.

title: Índia
label: Mr. Bongo
description: With 1973’s Índia, the samba singer Gal Costa cemented her status as one of Brazil’s biggest and most defiant stars, collaborating with Caetano Veloso and Gilberto Gil in the process.

title: Add Violence EP
label: The Null Corporation
description: Nine Inch Nails’ second EP in a year is as perplexing and immediate as their first. Trent Reznor has lost none of his power to discomfit and intimidate.

title: Hip Mobility
label: Butterscotch
description: Constructed around archival NASA recordings, the latest from Wilco’s Mikael Jorgensen’s features meticulous, pop-molded instrumentals that feel just a little incomplete without a vocal narrative.

title: Moonshine Freeze
label: Rough Trade
description: With her new record as This Is the Kit, singer-songwriter Kate Stables offers a collection of sparse folk that takes on the mysteries of mortality with a wizened sigh.

title: Eucalyptus
label: Domino
description: Dave Porter’s latest album as Avey Tare is ambitious and inspiring. His painful, deeply personal, and intimate songs never are in constant search for new sounds and emotions.

title: Lust for Life
label: Interscope
description: The fourth full-length from Lana Del Rey is sincere, sublime and beautiful. As personal as it is impressionistic, Lust for Life is the emergence of a great American storyteller.

title: Bedouine
label: Spacebomb
description: The soulful debut from Syrian-born Azniv Korkejian showcases the depth of her songwriting and uses Spacebomb’s retro sound to create an exquisite, subtle, and wide-eyed collection of songs.

title: Pariah
label: Objects Limited
description: Twenty years into her career, after a hiatus of more than a decade, the Chicago footwork producer finally releases her debut album, taking apart her hometown’s club genres and recombining them in captivatingly original ways.

title: Sacred Hearts Club
label: Columbia
description: Mark Foster enlists more beat-filled haze for his third album, a tuneful but confounding modern pop event that lands somewhere between the Beach Boys and Just Blaze.

title: Sunday Songs
label: First Terrace
description: The composer Peter Broderick assembles a 35-strong choir of professional and amateur singers, and the results are like a secular church service: rough around the edges, punctuated with laughter, and joyous.

title: Fabriclive 93
label: Fabric
description: In his first Fabric mix under his Daphni alias, Caribou’s Dan Snaith zigzags his way through an eclectic set of edits and original productions.

title: Full Flower
label: Topshelf
description: The Baltimore band’s full-length debut uses slowcore not just as a variant of indie rock, but also a framework to make real-deal pop songs that make boredom sound utterly desirable.

title: Dots and Loops
label: Duophonic
description: Stereolab’s masterpiece fused analog with digital, past with future, Marxism with the commercial magic of music through a pristine record that defined an age of “recombinant pop.”

title: Leave Home
label: Rhino
description: This 40th anniversary three-disc reissue of the second Ramones album is littered with alternate mixes, all attempting to achieve a precise balance of muscle and effervescence.

title: Pagan Day / Allegory and Self
label: Sacred Bones
description: With post-Throbbing Gristle outfit Psychic TV, Genesis P-Orridge bent together the opposing poles of psychedelia and industrial music. Two new reissues show the extremities of their early catalog.

title: Square One
label: Smalltown Supersound
description: The Scandinavian disco luminaries join for an album that draws on space rock, dub, leftfield disco, and post-punk, made more for the mind than the dancefloor.

title: Lo Tom
label: Barsuk
description: For his latest LP, Pedro the Lion’s David Bazan formed a new band and returned to straight-ahead guitar rock. It’s got some of his most aerodynamic songs in over a decade, but suffers from redundancy.

title: Dead Saints Chronicles
label: Marionette
description: The German electronic musician explores deep, fluid percussive grooves in the same vein as his work with the late drummer Jaki Liebezeit.

title: Raskit
label: Dirtee Stank
description: With the grime revival in full swing, one of the genre’s elder statesmen returns with an album that’s torn between his UK roots and his affinity for American hip-hop.

title: Flower Boy
label: Columbia
description: On Tyler’s sincere and most accomplished album, he gets to the essence of what he's been chiseling at: the angst of a missed connection, the pain of unrequited love, and navigating youthful ennui.

title: Several Shades of the Same Color
label: Spectral Sound
description: The Brooklyn producer Max Ravitz makes homespun techno with lush pads, errant noise, and intricate rhythms. His latest LP offers variations on the sound made with a limited palette.

title: Mellow Waves
label: Rostrum
description: Returning to his long-running solo act, the Japanese producer Keigo Oyamada aims for the glowing emotional core of his playful, retro-futuristic aesthetic.

title: One Night Only
label: RCA
description: On his major label debut, the once-scrappy Boston rapper Cousin Stizz flaunts his wealth as well as his ear for distinctive, minimalist production.

title: Sounds of Crenshaw, Vol. 1
label: Ropeadope
description: After handling production for Kendrick Lamar, Terrace Martin’s work as a bandleader comes into focus with quiet storm, R&B, and deep grooves that show the composer and instrumentalist making strides.

title: Solid Rain
label: Semiotext(e)
description: The eclectic new album from L.A. indie outfit Holy Shit is also the first musical offering from Semiotext(e), the publishing house run in part by I Love Dick author Chris Kraus.

title: Jean​-​Jacques Perrey et son Ondioline
label: Forgotten Futures
description: In a collection of unreleased and rarely heard recordings, the French electronic music pioneer displays his mastery of an early proto-synthesizer.

title: Blast Off Through the Wicker
label: Western Vinyl
description: Here We Go Magic frontman Luke Temple’s new project is his most cohesive yet. As Art Feynman, he emerges as a cool purveyor of dub-kraut.

title: EP #260
label: Sacred Bones
description: With his band SQÜRL, the legendary filmmaker Jim Jarmusch makes drone-oriented music that’s more about texture than motion. Their latest EP is uniquely physical.

title: Jungle Rules
label: Bad Boy / Epic
description: With features from Future, Quavo, Young Thug, and T.I., French Montana returns newly motivated with his sophomore album, which acts as a funnel for everyone’s strongest qualities but his own.

title: Infinity Ultra
label: Planet Mu
description: With songs that travel great distances between the poles of ambient and noise music, Claude Speeed’s latest is a mercurial set, capturing with great skill a kind of restless, sourceless anxiety.

title: Mura Masa
label: Anchor Point
description: Alex Crossan’s debut album is a love letter to multicultural London that’s informed by the 21-year-old musician’s insular upbringing and abetted by a number of high-profile guests.

title: Soft Sounds From Another Planet
label: Dead Oceans
